texts.en:
Shaheen akhtar baji has been a citizen of Lahore, in Pakistan, for the last eleven years. She completed her education through 5th standard, but she couldn’t study further because her school was based on 1st standard through 5th standard. For 6th standard she had to enroll in secondary school, but her father couldn’t admit her because of the high fees charged by the school. Shaheen baji got married to a man whose name is A. G., and he is a driver by profession. He has driven an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle) for the last five years. Driving an auto-rickshaw became her family's business. Her first two sons are also drivers of auto-rickshaws. Shaheen baji has successfully repaid her first loan from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan). Now she is applying for a loan to repair her sons' auto-rickshaws so that they will be able to continue their work and earn income. 

She is the group leader of more women from her locality. Saima baji wants a loan to buy paints to sell. Hanifan baji wants a loan to buy plastic utensils to sell. Zeb-un-Nisa baji wants a loan to buy supplies (chairs, razors and mirror) for her salon. Mumtaz baji wants a loan to buy a lath machine. 

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

texts.vi:
Chị L. năm nay 46 tuổi. Gia đình chị có 2 con đã trưởng thành. Chị tham gia Quỹ Tình thương từ năm 1998. Hiện tại công việc đem lại nguồn thu chính cho gia đình chị là từ kinh doanh hàng ăn và làm nghề đúc đồng ( đúc các sản phẩm thủ công mỹ nghệ, tranh cung cấp cho các đại lý và bán lẻ cho người tiêu dùng) với thu nhập 4.000.000đ/ tháng.
 Vòng vốn tới chị mong muốn được vay 20.000.000đ  để đầu tư mua đồng về đúc.
texts.en:
Mrs. L. is 46 years old. She has two grown-up children. She has participated in TYM Fund since 1998. Currently, the businesses that bring the main source of income for her family are food selling and bronze casting (casting of traditional art products to supply to sales agents or sell directly to consumers) with an income of VND 4,000,000 per month.

In this loan cycle she wishes to borrow VND 20,000,000 to buy more bronze to cast.

Translated from Vietnamese by Tu Duong, Kiva Volunteer

loans.name: Duong Thi

texts.vi: Chị Dương Thị Huyền năm nay 41 tuổi.Chị tham gia Quỹ Tình thương từ năm 2002. Ban đầu chị vay vốn để đi thu mua phế liệu và chăn nuôi. Sau 7 năm tham gia Quỹ tình thương với việc sử dụng vốn vay hiệu quả và được vay mức vốn lớn dần hiện tại  gia điìn chị đã  đầu tư  mở được một xưởng đúc đồng nhỏ với thu nhập 4.000.000đ/ tháng. Vòng vốn tới chị mong muốn được vay 10.000.000đ  để đầu tư mua nguyên liệu phục vụ cho công việc sản xuất của gia đình.
texts.en:
Mrs. Duong Thi H. is 41 years old. She has participated in TYM Fund since 2002. Initially, she borrowed money for scrap material collection and livestock raising. After 7 years of participation to the Fund, with the effective use of the loans and the increase in credit limit, her family has set up a small bronze casting workshop with an income of VND 4,000,000 per month.

In this loan cycle, she wishes to borrow VND 10,000,000 to buy more materials for the family's business.

Translated from Vietnamese by Tu Duong, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy materials for bronze casting business

texts.en:
Tasleem baji is a forty-nine-year-old married lady and has been a citizen of Lahore, in Pakistan, for the last twenty-one years. Tasleem baji is married to a man named M. M. who is a watchman at a local school earning a monthly wage. His earnings are very little which forced Tasleem baji to find work, so she operates a sewing business. She is the mother of seven children, five sons and two daughters. Her oldest son is an auto-rickshaw driver (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle). The second and third sons work in a factory, earning monthly wages. The younger of them manufactures sewing machines. Tasleem baji sews clothes to pay the school fees of her youngest son and her daughters.  She successfully repaid her first two loans from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan). Now she is applying again for a loan to repair her elder son’s auto-rickshaw. 

Tasleem baji is the group leader of four other women from her locality. Naseem baji wants a loan to buy an auto-rickshaw. Samina baji wants a loan to repair her vehicle named “Shahzore”. Mussarat baji wants a loan to repair the motorbikes she rents out. Gulzar baji wants a loan to buy vehicle oil to sell. 

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

Badam gull is the group leader of Badam gull's group. There are three members in this group. All of them would like to receive money for their businesses.

Fatama and Badam gull want to take a loan for their tailoring business. They want to buy necessary materials for their business. Hanna gull wants to take a loan for her quilt business. She wants to increase her stock. They are thankful for the loan of 30,000 Afghanis. 

They want to say that this loan is very useful because it can provide a good chance for poor entrepreneurs to expand their businesses.

loans.name: Parveen Akhtar M. Khalid Group

texts.en:
Parveen akhtar baji is a forty-seven-year-old married lady and has been a citizen of Lahore, in Pakistan, for the last ten years. Parveen baji’s husband, M. K., has been in the scrap business for the past six years. Parveen baji is the mother of four children - three sons and one daughter. Her sons are involved in their father’s scrap business. Her daughter reads in 9th standard and wants to get a higher education after completing her 10th standard. Parveen baji respects her wish, and to help realize that wish she embroiders clothes and makes money selling them in a market. She successfully repaid her first two loans from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan). Now she is applying again for a loan to buy scrap (plastic bottles, waste papers) to sell. 

Parveen baji is the group leader of four other women from her locality. Another Parveen akthar baji wants a loan to buy rice to sell. Mussarat shaheen baji wants a loan to buy clothes to sell. Munawar baji wants a loan to buy an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle). Suraiya baji wants a loan to buy scrap for a scrap business. 

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy scrap for scrap business

loans.name: Sabra M. Habib Group

texts.en:
Sabra baji is a forty-five-year-old married lady and has been a citizen of Lahore, in Pakistan, for the last twenty-seven years. Her husband, M. H., is a farmer and belongs to an agricultural group. She is the mother of six children - two sons and four daughters. Her elder son drives an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle) and her younger son is involved with his father’s agriculture business. Her daughters are enrolled in a local school and are getting their education. Sabra baji has a decorative embroidery business. She embroiders clothes on order and charges $3 per embroidered dress. She uses her income to pay school fees for her daughters. She successfully repaid her first two loans from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan). Now she is applying again for a loan to buy materials (beads, colored thread and clothes) for her decorative embroidery business. 

Sabra baji is the group leader of two other women from her locality. Parveen akthar baji wants a loan to buy clothes to sell. Hamidan begum baji wants a loan to buy another sewing machine for her tailoring business. 

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: to buy materials for decorative embroidery business

loans.name: Myrna

texts.en: Myrna A. is a simple woman. She is forty-eight years old, married, and lives in Punta Blanca, Mobod, Oroquieta City. She has three children. Her husband drives his own motorcycle. In order for her to help her husband, she decided to open a “sari-sari” (general) store adjacent to their house. It started with a capital of only $11. Her primary customers are neighbors & relatives. She was able to manage the business so well that they were able to buy their food with the income from the “sari-sari” store. Myrna is also thankful to the Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative, because it helped her in the expansion of her store, specifically with financial matters. She became a member of the co-op in December of 2006. She has received loans several times. Now, she is applying for only $50 for additional merchandise for sale. She’s looking forward to a comfortable life and plans to expand her business into a grocery store someday.

loans.use: to buy additional merchandise for sale

texts.ru: Клиент Хайдаров Ибодулло проживает в районе Руми, высшее образования не имеет, в возрастом 39 лет. Женат имеет 4 - ех детей.Сам клиент занимается торговлей уже более шести лет.На получившие деньги клиент хочет расширить ассортимерт продугции.
texts.en:
Ibodullo H. lives in the Rumi district, is 39 years old, and has no higher education. He is married and has four children. This client has already been in business for over six years. He wants to use the loan to expand his inventory of goods.

Translated from Russian by Anna Brown, Kiva Volunteer

loans.name: Shabana Zafar Iqbal Group

texts.en:
Shabana baji is a thirty-nine-year-old married lady and has been a resident of Lahore, in Pakistan, for the last twenty-five years. She is married to Z. I., and he has had a carpet weaving business for the last six years. He learned this art from his father. Shabana baji is the mother of four children - two sons and two daughters. All of her children are getting an education from a school which is located near their house. Shabana baji helps her husband in his carpet weaving business. She is applying for a loan to buy materials (colored thread, tools) for weaving carpets. 

Shabana baji is the group leader of another four women from her locality. Shahnaz baji wants a loan to buy groceries for her grocery shop. Razia begum baji wants a loan to buy a molding machine. Shahnaz kosar baji wants a loan to buy electrical supplies (wires, switch boards) to sell. Safia baji wants a loan to buy a washing machine for her laundry business. 

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: to buy materials for carpet weaving business

texts.en:
Nargis baji is a 39-year-old married lady. She has been a citizen of a city named Lahore in Pakistan for the past 11 years. Nargis baji is married to M. L., who has driven a local, 32-seat bus for the past six years. Nargis baji is the mother of two kids: one son and one daughter. Her children do not go to school. Nargis baji has a wish to admit her kids to a school so that they are able to secure their future.

Nargis baji is a very determined lady who is working hard to achieve her wish. She sells thread by going to different shops on foot and earns some income. She successfully repaid her two loans from Kiva's partner Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan). Now she is applying again for a loan to buy more thread to sell.

Nargis baji is the group leader of another four women from her neighborhood. Shamim akhtar baji wants a loan to buy an electric sewing machine for sewing clothes. Hina baji wants a loan to repair her auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle). Abida baji wants a loan to buy vehicle spare parts to sell. Rubina kosar baji wants a loan to buy a sewing machine for sewing clothes.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.name: Bushra Razaq Razaq Ahmad Group

texts.en:
Bushra R. baji is a 36-year-old married lady and a citizen of a city named Lahore in Pakistan for the past 14 years. Her husband, R. A., has been an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle) driver for the past five years. Bushra baji is the mother of five kids: three sons and two daughters. All of her kids are getting an education from a school located near the house.

Bushra baji operates a clothes-sewing business. She charges $2 per dress. Mostly her customers are her neighbors. She successfully repaid her two loans from Kiva's partner Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan). Now she is applying again for a loan to repair her husband’s auto-rickshaw.

Bushra baji is the group leader of another four women from her area. Shahnaz begum baji wants a loan to buy ready-made garments to sell. Farzana baji wants a loan to buy furniture for her tuition (tutoring) center. Fozia baji wants a loan to buy scrap for her scrap business. Abida parveen baji wants a loan to buy material (lentils, cooking oil and spices) for her food-selling business.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To repair an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle)

loans.name: Qamar Group

texts.en:
Qamar is the group leader of this group. They all live in district 11. Each of them would like to take a loan for their own business. The total amount of their group loan is 50000 Afghanis.

Nagyaly wants to take a loan for his business. M. hamad wants to take a loan for his tailoring business. He wants to buy two new machines for his shop. Qamar wants to take a loan for her bakery. Rakhshana wants to take a loan to buy materials for her quilt business. Nahed wants to take a loan for her brother’s general store to buy necessary materials for his shop.       

They are confident that they can have a good profit and can run their business in a good way with the money they receive. They all are happy about the loan process and want to say that it can support entrepreneurs a lot.

loans.use: Buy materials and enlarge their businesses

loans.name: Rahbarjon

texts.en:
A. Rahbarjon first applied to Kiva's partner MicroInvest in 2009. She had heard good responses about the MicroInvest loan program from friends and decided to apply for a business-development loan. Working in the local bazaar, Rahbarjon meets with hard competition. Rahbarjon sells tires and women's hats. She has to carry modern styles to have repeat customers, so Rahbarjon goes two or three times per month to Byshkek or Istaravshan for the new seasonal and modern assortment.

Rahbarjon has been engaged in the commercial service trade for three years and she dreams of a good trade outlet opening where she may sell her goods. Rhbarjon applies to Kiva for a business-support loan of 1600 STJ for six months to rent a new trade outlet in the central crowed bazaar that will permit her to increase inventory turnover and attract new clients.

loans.use: To rent a new trade outlet in the central crowed bazaar

loans.name: Enriqueta

texts.en:
Enriqueta S., a mother of 10, presently resides at Old Road, Waterfall Balingsag, Misamis Oriental in the Southern Philippines. Enriqueta realizes that with their present situation, she and her husband must work to provide for the needs of the family. Raising the 10 children isn't an easy task but with their joined forces, she knows they will be able to surpass any problems that will come along the way.

Her husband, Benjamin S., is a hardworking farmer who works all day on the farm to ensure that their daily consumption needs will be met. As for her help, she engages in different business ventures, like buying and selling green bananas, peddling food, selling firewood, and buying and selling foot-long hot dogs. She plans on managing a carenderia (food store) of her own in the future. She seeks a loan amounting to PHP 12,000 for additional capital for her foot-long hot dog business.

loans.use: Additional capital for foot-long hot dog business

location.town: Old Road, Waterfall, Balingasag, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Anecita

texts.en:
Anecita A. D. is a resident of Kabakungan, Claveria Misamis Oriental, Southern Philippines. She is married to Luis D. and they have 2 children.

Her husband is currently the elected councilor of the village. As a wife, she wants to help her husband build a better future for the family and wants to give financial assistance for their everyday expenses. Currently, she is into a food vending business with her own food stall. Her customers are her neighbors, peddlers, and passers-by. Her greatest dream is to see her children graduate and earn a degree. To expand her business and be able to cater for the village needs, she is applying for a loan amounting to PHP 7,000 to purchase ingredients for additional food for her food stall.

loans.use: purchase additional food ingredients for her food vending business.

texts.ru: Клиентка Саижамилова Зайнаби проживающая в районе Руми,49 лет замужем имеет четырёх дитей.Дети клиентки работают в России.Клиентка образования не имеет. Сама клиентка занимается животноводством, этим видом деятельности занимается уже более 12 лет.На получившие деньги клиентка хочет купить мелкорогатый скот с дольнейшей продажи.На получиную прибыль, клиентка хочет поженить сыновей.
texts.en:
Client Zaynabi S. lives in the Rumi district, is married and has four children who all work in Russia. She has no formal education. Zaynabi practices animal husbandry, as she has for over 12 years. With the funds received she wants to buy some small livestock for later sale. She would like to use the profit earned to marry her sons.

Translated from Russian by Anna Brown, Kiva Volunteer

loans.name: Julieta

texts.en: Julieta J. G., 56, is separated and has bravely raised her two children with her income from the small variety store in her house. Julieta is proud to be a member of PMPC and has accessed 11 loans already.  She said that with her little business, Paglaum has been a consistent partner in all her financial needs. From her loan she is planning to buy assorted goods for the store. She hopes to expand from a variety store to a mini-mart someday.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory of soft drinks, bags of rice, and toiletries

loans.name: Mehar Khan M.sadiq Group

texts.en:
Mehar K. baji is 53 years old and a married lady and citizen of a city named Lahore, Pakistan for the past 21 years. Mehar baji is the mother of one son who is 15 years old and works in his father’s scrap business. Mehar K. baji successfully repaid her two loans from Asasah (a micro-finance institute in Pakistan). Now she is applying again for a loan to buy scrap for her husband’s scrap business.

Mehar baji is the group leader for another four women from her locality. Bashiran baji wants a loan to buy an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle). Khatoon baji wants a loan to buy seasonal fruit for her fruit-selling business. Rubina baji wants a loan to buy CDs for her CD shop. Asma baji wants a loan to buy a sewing machine for sewing clothes.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy scrap for scrap business

loans.name: Melodina

texts.en: Mrs. Melodina C. is a 40-year-old mother of two children in elementary school. Her husband is a hollow block maker. His income isn’t enough for them to live on, so Melodina was eager to open a variety store to help meet the family’s needs. She joined HSPFI and received a loan of PHP5000 for initial capital. Now her business is growing, as is demand, so she is requesting a loan of PHP 8000 to purchase additional grocery items. This will allow her to meet the needs of her customers and support her children’s education.

loans.use: To purchase grocery items for her variety store

location.town: Pagatpat, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Zahida Tasneem Naseem Akhtar Group

texts.en:
Zahida Tasneem N. A. lives in Lahore, Pakistan and is the leader of a group loan which she shares with three other women from her community. She is 47 years old and married with three children: two sons and one daughter. Her eldest son works with his father while the others attend a local school. 

Her husband, N. A., is a cobbler who earns his income by fulfilling orders from shoe companies. He has been making shoes for five years. Zahida is applying for a loan to buy leather for her husband’s shoe making business. 

The other members of the group will use the loan as follows: Rozina will use her portion of the loan to buy bed sheets to sell. Sakina would like to buy clothes to sell. Mussarat will purchase a sewing machine so she can sew clothes. 

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members and each of them will invest in their own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy leather for shoe making

texts.ru: Клиентка Турсунова Махбуба,возратом 50  лет замужем, имеет  троих детей  проживает в районе Руми.Образования среднее.Муж клиентки занимается услугой такси.Сама клиентка занимается торговлей материалов, на местном рынке этим видом деятельности занимается уже более 10 лет.На полученные деньги, клиентка увеличит свой товар это поможет ей увеличить своих клиентов.
texts.en:
Mahbuba T. is 50 years old, married, has three children, and lives in the Rumi district. She has a high school education. The client's husband provides taxi services. She herself sells fabric at the local market, a business she has been in for over 10 years. With the loan, Mahbuba will increase her inventory, helping her to expand her customer base.

Translated from Russian by Anna Brown, Kiva Volunteer

loans.name: Viola's Group

texts.en:
Viola N. is the leader of Bujagali group in Jinja. 

Viola has a tailoring business where she earns a living making and mending clothes. She tailors gomesi (traditional formal dresses), bitenge (fabric printed with colorful patterns that are tailored and worn by people all over Uganda), and children’s clothes. She has been doing this work for a long time and has taken loans over the past 6 years. In addition to this business, she is grateful to have a farm where she raises cows, goats, and pigs. Viola is requesting a loan to help purchase materials for sewing, pay school fees for her children, and help with her farm.

loans.use: Buy sewing materials like fabrics and thread, pay school fees, and help on farm.

loans.name: Kaja Group

texts.en:
Mariam S., age 45, is married with three children ages 29, 27, and 12. She sells cloth. She started this business three years ago and works daily from 10am until 4pm. She is able to earn a monthly profit of around US$ 112.

This will be Mariam’s third loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. She used the previous loans to increase her capital and has repaid the loans successfully. She hopes for a third loan to increase her stock and buy fabrics and sarongs.

Mariam will share this loan with her loan group, Kaja, which totals 17 members. The members of the group hold each other accountable in paying back their loans. In the picture, Mariam is just behind the man with a striped T-shirt.

loans.use: To expand her business and sell fabrics and sarongs

loans.name: Roohi Bano  Akhtar Hussain Group

texts.en:
Roohi bano baji is 40 years old married lady and a citizen of a city named Lahore, Pakistan for the past 50 years. Roohi baji married a man whose name is A. H. and he runs a shop where he prepares embroidered clothes with the help of an embroidery machine. Roohi baji is the mother of five kids: four daughters and one son. All of her kids are getting an education from a local school. Roohi baji operates a decorative embroidery business. She prepares embroidered dresses by taking orders from her neighbors and relatives. She charges $3 per embroidered dress. She is applying for a loan to buy another embroidery machine to expand her husband’s decorative embroidery business. 

Roohi bano baji is the group leader of two other women from her locality. Zeenat naz baji wants a loan to buy thread to sell. Amna baji wants a loan to buy beams for her shuttering business. 

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy another embroidery machine for decorative embroidery business

loans.name: Magreth

texts.en:
Mambo (greetings) from Tanzania! This is 58-year-old Magreth J. T.. She is a widow with six children. She has been running a clothing business since 2007. She sells clothes of different types. She works at the business for 12 hours per day, seven days per week, and is assisted by one employee. Magreth currently earns about $100 a month from her business. She is requesting a loan in order to purchase stock in bulk. In the future, she plans to increase the quantity and range of the stock. Magreth thanks you for your support!

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through micro-leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility.

Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of micro-leasing is that is allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase stock in bulk for her business

loans.name: Gorret's Group

texts.en:
Gorret N. is the leader of Ivunamba group in Jinja. In the photo, she is with Robinah L.. 

Gorret has a business selling matooke, a stew of plantains, beef, and dried fish cooked in a beef and tomato stock. She gets some of the plantains for the matooke from her farm. She buys the rest from other farmers for increased profits. 

Robinah has a poultry business in which she raises local and exotic chickens for sale. Both ladies would like a loan to invest more in their businesses.

loans.use: To buy matooke and chicken feed

loans.name: Mukhtaran Malik M. Ramzan Group

texts.en:
Mukhtaran baji, the wife of M. M. R., has lived in Lahore, Pakistan for the past 30 years. Mukhtaran baji is the mother of three sons, all of whom work in a factory for a monthly wage. Mukhtaran baji sews clothes. She charges $2 per dress. Her husband has operated a scrap business for the past 10 years. She is applying for a loan to buy scrap for his scrap business. 

Mukhtaran baji is the leader of a group of four women from her locality. Nasreen Bano baji wants a loan to buy leather for her shoe-making business. Suraiya baji wants a loan to buy thread to sell. Shamshad Begum baji wants a loan to buy a sewing machine to sew clothes. Javeda Kalsoom baji wants a loan to buy medicines for her medical store. 

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

Note: 'Baji,' which means 'older sister,' is a term of respect for women in Pakistan.

loans.use: To buy scrap for scrap business

texts.en:
Margret I. sells tomatoes, cabbage, and sweet potatoes and is requesting a loan to expand her business.  Margret is 40 years old and is married. Her husband is a teacher. She has five children who go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a shop. 

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.name: Nguyen Thi

texts.vi: Chị Nguyễn Thị Hưng ở Quảng Xương, Thanh Hóa. Gia đình chị có 2 con nhỏ và đều đang đi học. Chị tham gia Quỹ từ năm 2006. Thu nhập hiện tại của gia đình chị là từ công việc rửa, sửa xe của chồng và từ chăn nuôi, làm ruộng của chị với thu nhập 3.500.000đ/ tháng Vòng vốn tới chị mong muốn được vay thêm 9.000.000 để mua thêm đồ nghề sửa xe cho chồng, mở rộng cửa hàng.
texts.en:
Mrs. Nguyen Thi H. lives in Quang Xuong, Thanh Hoa. She has two small children who are going to school. She has participated in TYM Fund since 2006. Currently, the income of the family is from bike wash, bike repair by the husband, and farming, livestock raising by herself with a total income of VND 3,500,000 per month.

In this loan cycle, she wishes to borrow VND 9,000,000 to buy additional tools for bike repair for her husband and to expand the workshop.

Translated from Vietnamese by Tu Duong, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy tools for bike repair and expand the workshop

loans.name: Asifa Begum M.hanif Group

texts.en:
Asifa Begum baji is a 56-year-old widow who has been a citizen of Lahore, Pakistan for the past 50 years. Her husband left her with no financial resources. Asifa baji worked hard to survive. She has two sons. She started selling ready-made garments in the cloth shops. With the income that she earned, she opened a shop in which she sells ready-made garments, and then she handed the shop over to her eldest son. Her younger son sells medicine. Asifa baji is applying for a loan to buy ready-made garments for her son’s garment business.

Asifa baji is the leader of a group of five women from her locality. Samia Shahzadi baji wants a loan to buy thread to sell. Kishwar Begum baji wants a loan to buy vehicle spare parts to sell. Farah Naz baji wants a loan to buy a welding machine. Yasmeen Kosar baji wants a loan to buy beams for her shuttering business. 

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

Note: "Baji," which means "older sister," is a term of respect for women in Pakistan.

loans.use: To buy ready-made garments to sell

texts.vi: Chị Nguyễn Thị Dần, năm nay 54 tuổi ở Quảng Xương, Thanh Hóa. Từ sau khi tham gia Quỹ vào năm 2008, chị đã có thêm nguồn vốn để đầu tư cho công việc kinh daonh của gia đình. Hiện nay, thu nhập chính của gia đình là  hơn 100.000/ ngày từ hoạt động bán lân đạm và ghim chiếu của chồng. Vòng vốn tới chị mong muốn được vay thêm 6.000.000 để mua thêm đạm về bán, tăng thêm thu nhập cho gia đình.
texts.en:
Mrs. Nguyen Thi D., 54 years old, lives in Quang Xuong, Thanh Hoa. After joining the Fund in 2008, she has borrowed money to invest in the family's business. Currently, the income of the family is VND100,000 per day from selling fertilizers and her husband's mat weaving.

In this loan cycle, she wishes to borrow VND6,000,000 to buy more nitrogenous fertilizer to resell to get extra income for the family.

Translated from Vietnamese by Tu Duong, Kiva Volunteer

loans.name: Kishwar Mubarak Ali Group

texts.en:
Kishwar baji is a 25-year-old married woman who lives in Lahore, Pakistan. Kishwar baji’s husband, M. A., has been selling construction supplies for the past 10 years. Kishwar baji is the mother of four children, two sons and two daughters, who are all enrolled in school. Kishwar baji sells bed sheets to her neighbors. With the income that she  earned, she renovated her house. She is applying for a loan to buy sand and cement for her husband's construction business. 

Kishwar baji is the leader of a group of four women from her locality. Parveen baji wants a loan to buy a lath machine. Nazia baji and Mumtaz baji each want a loan to buy thread to sell. 

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

Note: "Baji," which means "older sister," is a term of respect for women in Pakistan.

loans.use: To buy construction supplies to sell

texts.vi: Chị Nguyễn Thị Sỹ, 50 tuổi ở Quảng Xương, Thanh Hóa, làm nghề dệt chiếu. Gia đình chị có hai con đều đã lớn và đã đi làm, chồng chị là thợ sửa xe máy. Chị tham gia Quỹ từ năm 2005, với việc làm ăn hiệu quả kinh tế gia đình chị đang ngày càng ổn định hơn. Hiện nay, thu nhập trung bình của gia đình chị là 175.000/ngày. Vòng vốn tới chị mong muốn được vay thêm 8.000.000 để đầu tư mở rộng cửa hàng sửa chữa xe máy của chồng.
texts.en:
Mrs. Nguyen Thi Si, 50 years old, lives in Quang Xuong, Thanh Hoa. She weaves sleeping mats. She has two grown-up children who are working. Her husband repairs motorcycles. She joined TYM Fund in 2005, and with the effective use of loans, the economic condition of the family has been improved. Currently, the average income of the family is VND 175,000 per day.

In this loan cycle, she wishes to borrow VND8,000,000 to expand the motorcycle repair workshop.

Translated from Vietnamese by Tu Duong, Kiva Volunteer

Mugamba Hellen is the leader of the Main Street Group in Jinja. She is a young businesswoman who sells used shoes, mostly for ladies and children, that she displays in a stall outside a shop in Jinja. This is her second loan with the group. The first one helped her increase the stock of shoes that she sells.

Hellen is still a student pursuing her dream career. Her shop has helped her so much during her school times with school fees and upkeep. She hopes that if she ever finds a job, she will keep her shoe-selling business by employing someone to manage it. She needs a loan to help buy more shoes from Jinja and Kampala to sell.

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en:
Agnes M. is currently in the business of selling bread. She is requesting a loan to expand her business. Agnes is 37 and married. Her husband is a peasant. She has three children who go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay school fees for the children.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations.

BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted toward returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Pay school fees for the children

loans.name: Nguyen Thi

texts.vi: Chị Nguyễn Thị Tươi, năm nay 28 tuổi, ở Thanh Hóa. Anh chị có hai con nhỏ và đều còn đang đi học. Chị tham gia Quỹ từ năm 2007. Thu nhập chính của gia đình chị hiện nay là từ hoạt động chăn nuôi, dệt chiếu của chị và việc chạy xe công nông chở vật liệu cho các công trường của chồng. Vòng vay tới chị mong muốn vay  9.000.000 đ để mua thêm lác dệt chiếu, và mua thêm lợn để chăn nuôi
texts.en:
Mrs. Nguyen Thi T., 28 years old, lives in Thanh Hoa. She has two small children who are going to school. She has participated in TYM Fund since 2007. The sources of income of her family are from livestock raising and mat weaving by herself, and from materials transportation service using his own truck by her husband.

In this loan cycle, she wishes to borrow VND 9,000,000 to buy supplies for mat weaving, and buy pigs to raise.

Translated from Vietnamese by Tu Duong, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: buy supplies for mat weaving, and buy pigs to raise.

loans.name: David's Group

texts.en:
K. David is the leader of the Gamba group in Lugazi. He is a fisherman on the Senyi landing site in Bbogo. He is happy that ever since he joined his lending group, life has changed. He is able to run his business, he has a farm where he grows food both for sale and for home consumption, and he is able to have his boats serviced when the need arises.

He has two boats now and would like to buy a new engine for his second boat for efficiency. He is now happy that his children go to school and he is able to clear their school fees on time. He has a plan of growing the number of boats into a fleet so that he can rent out the rest for increased profits.

loans.use: Buying a new engine for his second boat

texts.en:
Lucia M. is in the business of selling biscuits and sweets at a shop. She is requesting a loan to expand her business. Lucia is 37 and married to a security guard. She has three children who go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open a hotel.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations.

BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted toward returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.name: Rani Nazir Hussain Group

texts.en:
Rani baji is a 39-year-old lady and a citizen of  Lahore, Pakistan for the last 22 years. Rani baji’s husband is N. H.. He manufactures car seats and sells them in the market to earn a profit. Rani baji is the mother of one son whose name is Waqas. He is involved in his father’s business. Rani baji operates a business selling bed sheets. She has been selling bed sheets for the last five years.  Rani baji is applying for a loan to buy leather for her husband’s car-seat-making business. 

Rani baji is the group leader for another six women from her locality. Shahida baji wants a loan to buy seasonal fruits for her fruit-selling business. Misbah baji wants a loan to buy a lathe machine. Bushra baji and Rehana baji each want a loan to buy leather for their shoe-making business. Safia baji wants a loan to buy thread to sell. Razia baji wants a loan to buy vehicle spare parts to sell. 

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy leather to make car seats

texts.vi: Chị Nguyễn Thị Lý, năm nay 34 tuổi ở Thanh Hóa. Gia đình chị có 2 con nhỏ và đều đang đi học. Chị tham gia Quỹ từ năm 2006, với những số vốn vay được đã giúp chị mở rộng chăn nuôi, tạo thêm thu nhập và có điều kiện cho con ăn học. Hiện nay, thu nhập chính của gia đình là từ việc chăn nuôi, làm ruộng và dệt chiếu của chị, bên cạnh đó chồng chị lái xe tải cũng tạo thêm thu nhập cho gia đình. Thu nhập bình quân đạt 4.000.000đ/ tháng.  Vòng vay tới chị mong muốn được vay 9.000.000 để mua thêm 24 con lợn, mở rộng chăn nuôi.
texts.en:
Mrs. Nguyen Thi L., 34 years old, lives in Thanh Hoa province. She has two small children who are going to school. She has participated in the Fund since 2006. The loans has helped her to expand livestock raising business, earn extra income, and pay tuition fees for the children. CurrentL., the main sources of income of her famiL. are from livestock raising, farming, and mat weaving by herself, and from wages of her husband who is a truck driver. The average income of the famiL. is about VND 4,000,000 per month.

In this loan cycle, she wishes to borrow VND 9,000,000 to buy additional 24 pigs to raise

Translated from Vietnamese by Tu Duong, Kiva Volunteer

texts.vi: Chị Phạm Thị K., 53 tuổi. Gia đình chị có 6 người con trong đó có 3 con đang đi học.  . Chị tham gia Quỹ từ năm 2003, với việc làm ăn có hiệu quả, thu nhập của gia đình đã được cải thiện đáng kể, đã giúp anh chị có điều kiện nuôi con cái ăn học tốt hơn. Thu nhập bình quân hiện nay của gia đình chị gồm có dệt chiếu 25000/ngày, chồng làm công nhân lương  2000 000/tháng, ngoài ra gia đình còn có thêm sự hỗ trợ của các con.. Vòng vốn tới anh chị muốn vay thêm 8.000.000 để mua thêm lợn về nuôi.
texts.en:
Mrs. Phạm Thị K., is 53 years old. She has six children, three of which are still in school. She became a member of the TYM Fund in 2003, and thanks to the effective use of her loans the family’s income has increased significantly since then. This has allowed Mrs. K. and her husband to better provide for their children’s lives and education. Currently, the income of the family consists of an average of 25,000 VND (1.50 USD) per day from weaving straw mats and her husband’s monthly earnings as a laborer of 2,000,000 VND (119 USD). In addition, they receive some support from their grown children. In the next round of lending, she and her husband hope to borrow 8,000,000 VND (475 USD) to buy pigs to raise.

Translated from Vietnamese by Robert Sides, Kiva Volunteer

Mrs. Erlinda S. is 62 years old, married and has no children. She is a resident of Roxas, Zamboanga del Norte.  She currently manages her sari-sari store and her husband does farming.  She's an active member of Paglaum MPC, and has already accessed financial support from Paglaum twice before.  Now she is applying for another loan to purchase additional stock for her sari-sari store to help her husband.  She also hopes to save for their old age.

loans.name: Shahnaz Akhtar Riaz Hussain Group

texts.en:
Shahnaz akhtar baji is a 52-year-old married lady and a citizen of Lahore, Pakistan for the last 21 years. Shahnaz baji is the wife of R. H. who is a carpenter by profession. Shahanz baji is the mother of four kids: two daughters and two sons. Her sons are painters and paint houses and windows. Her elder daughter works in a factory for a monthly wage. Her younger daughter reads in the 10th standard. Shahnaz baji operates a decorative embroidery business. She prepares embroidered dresses and sells them in the cloth markets to earn an income. She successfully repaid her prior three loans from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan). Now she is applying again for a loan to buy material (beads, colored thread and sketches) for her decorative embroidery business. 

Shahnaz baji is the group leader of another four women from her locality. Jamila baji wants a loan to buy sanitary supplies (pipes, taps) to sell. Riffat naz baji wants a loan to buy nimko and chips for her canteen. Shakeela bano baji wants a loan to buy vehicle spare parts to sell. Suraiya baji wants a loan to buy cosmetics and a hair dryer for her parlor. 

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy materials for her embroidery business

texts.vi: Chị Văn Thị Chiến, 34 tuổi ở Quảng Xương Thanh Hóa. Chị có 3 con nhỏ và hiện còn đang đi học. Chị tham gia Quỹ từ năm 2005. Thu nhập hiện tại của gia đình chị là từ lương làm thợ điện  của chồng 1.000.000/ tháng và từ hoạt động chăn nuôi lợn gà của chị. Vòng vốn tới chị mong muốn được vay thêm 6.000.000 để mở cửa hàng  sửa chữa và bán đồ điện.
texts.en:
Mrs. Văn Thị Chiến, 34 years old, lives in Quảng Xương district, Thanh Hóa province. She has three young children who attend school. Mrs. Văn has participated in the TYM Fund since 2005. Currently, her family’s income consists of her husband’s wages as an electrician of 1,000,000 VND (58 USD) per month and her work raising pigs and chickens. In the next round of lending, she hopes to borrow 6,000,000 VND (350 USD) to open a shop selling and repairing electrical appliances.

Translated from Vietnamese by Robert Sides, Kiva Volunteer

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary D. is currently in the business of selling eggs and is requesting a loan to expand her business. Mary is 43 years old and is married to a husband who is a peasant. She has three children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a shop.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To expand her business and open up a shop

texts.en:
Khursheed baji is the wife of M. A.. She has been a resident of Lahore, Pakistan for the last 15 years. She is an uneducated lady because her father had little financial resources. Khursheed baji’s husband is a painter and sells paint. Khurhsheed baji has no kids so she mostly spends her time sewing clothes. Her activity gives her rewards in the shape of money. She successfully repaid her three loans from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan). Now she is applying again for a loan to buy more paint to sell. 

Khursheed baji is the group leader of another three women from her locality. Humaira baji wants a loan to buy meat to sell. Syeda bano baji and Shaheen A. baji each want a loan to buy an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle).

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

texts.vi: Chị Hoàng Thị L., 47 tuổi. Gia đình chị có hai con nhỏ, chồng chị làm thợ xây cũng hỗ trợ thêm thu nhập cho gia đình. Chị tham gia Quỹ từ năm 2005, với số vốn vay được đã giúp anh chị mở rộng chăn nuôi bò, gà, tăng thêm thu nhập cho gia đình. Hiện nay, thu nhập bình quân của gia đình chị là từ gà đẻ, lương của chồng làm thợ xây và hàng năm chị nuôi lợn thu khoảng 15 . 000 000đ. Vòng vốn tới chị mong muốn được vay 5.000.000 để mua thêm thức ăn chăn nuôi lợn
texts.en:
Mrs. Hoàng Thị L., 47 years old, has two school-age children. Her husband is a construction worker. She joined the TYM Fund in 2005 and used a loan to expand her operation raising cows and chickens, which subsequently increased the family income. Currently, her family’s annual earnings of about 15,000,000 VND (900 USD) come from her husband’s wages as a construction worker and from Mrs. L.’s work keeping laying hens and raising pigs. In the next round of lending, she hopes to borrow 5,000,000 VND (300 USD) to buy feed for her pigs.

Translated from Vietnamese by Robert Sides, Kiva Volunteer

loans.name: Syeda Naz Ejaz Sarwar Group

texts.en:
Syeda naz baji is 50 years old and has resided in the city of Lahore, Pakistan for the past 8 years. Syeda baji is the wife of E. S. who has run a butcher shop in the community for 5 years. Syeda baji is the mother of three kids: one son and two daughters. Her son also involve with her father’s butcher shop. Her daughters are getting an education from a school located near the house. Syeda baji successfully repaid last her three loans with Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan). Now, she is applying for a loan to buy animals (goats) for her husband’s butcher shop. 

Syeda naz baji is the group leader of three women from her locality. Nagina aziz baji wants a loan to buy seasonal fruits for her fruit selling business. Abida baji wants a loan to buy jewelry to sell. Nasreen baji wants a loan to buy meat to sell. 

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy animals for a butcher shop

texts.vi: Chị Nguyễn Thị Xuân ở Quảng Xương, Thanh Hóa. Năm nay chị 32 tuổi,có hai con nhỏ đang đi học. Chị tham gia Quỹ từ năm 2008. Thu nhập chính của gia đình chị hiện nay là từ dệt chiếu, chăn nuôi lợn, vịt,gà và từtiền công  chạy máy kéo của chồng 100.000/ngày. Vòng vốn tới chị mong muốn được vay thêm 9.000.000 để tu sửa máy móc và mua lác dệt chiếu.
texts.en:
Mrs. Nguyễn Thị Xuân lives in Quảng Xương district, Thanh Hóa province, and has participated in the TYM Fund since 2008. She is 32 years old and has two young children who attend school. Currently, the main sources of income for her family are weaving straw mats, raising pigs, ducks, and chickens, and wages her husband earns driving a tractor, for a total of about 100,000 VND (~6 USD) per day. In the next round of lending, she hopes to borrow 9,000,000 VND (525 USD) to repair her weaving machine and buy straw for making mats.

Translated from Vietnamese by Robert Sides, Kiva Volunteer

Elizberth P. is currently in the business of selling charcoal and onions and is requesting a loan to expand her business.  Elizberth is 50 years old and is married. Her husband is a peasant . She has 3 children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a shop. BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and provides legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as is measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.name: Irshad Bano Israr Ahmad Group

texts.en:
Irshad bano baji is the wife of I. A. and has resided in the city of Lahore, Pakistan for the past 30 years. Irshad baji is the mother of three sons. Her elder son has a vegetable selling business. The middle son is an electrician. Her younger son runs a grocery shop. Irshad baji’s husband has run a butcher shop in the community for  5 years. Irshad baji keeps herself busy with a clothes sewing  business. Her sewing activity gives her benefit of some income. She saves her income in a committee and plans to marry off her elder son with this committee savings account. She successfully repaid her three loans with Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan). Now she is applying for a loan to buy animals (goats) for her husband’s butcher shop.

Irshad bano baji is the group leader of four women from her locality. Shahida parveen baji wants a loan to buy an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle). Fahmida baji wants a loan to buy a molding machine. Raheela baji wants a loan to repair her vehicle named “shahzore”. Fozia baji wants a loan to buy animals (goats) for her butcher shop. 

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy animals for a butcher shop

texts.vi: Chị Nguyễn Thị Phấn, 41 tuổi ở Thanh Hóa. Gia đình chị có 3 con nhỏ và đang đi học, chồng chị lái xe tải với thu nhập 3.000.000/tháng. Chị tham Quỹ từ năm 2005, với công việc chính là làm máy sát thu bình quân 500.000/tháng và chăn nuôi lợn. Vòng vốn tới chị mong muốn được vay thêm 10.000.000 để đầu tư cho công việc chăn nuôi của gia đình
texts.en:
Mrs. Nguyễn Thị Phấn, 41 years old, lives in Thanh Hóa province. She has three young children who attend school. Her husband earns 3,000,000 VND (172 USD) per month as a truck driver. She joined the TYM Fund in 2005 and used her loan mainly to operate a rice-husking machine that earned her about 500,000 VND (29 USD) per month, and also to raise pigs. In the next round of lending, she hopes to borrow 10,000,000 VND (575 USD) to invest in the family business raising animals.

Translated from Vietnamese by Robert Sides, Kiva Volunteer

loans.name: Monica's Group

texts.en:
M. Monica is the leader of her group in Jinja. She is a poultry farmer and her main business is keeping chicken layers and broilers. She sells the eggs and the broilers for meat.

Monica has been able to benefit from her work because she feeds her birds on time, ensures that they have the best quality feeds, and above all, knows how to plan for the money she gets from her sales. As a result, Monica has been able to buy a sewing machine, which she uses to mend and make her customers’ clothes. She has also bought more household items. Monica also manages her small garden, where she grows food that is mostly for home consumption.

Monica needs a new loan to help with buying more day-old chicks to rear, plus feeds.

loans.use: To buy day-old chicks and chicken feed

texts.en:
Rose K. is currently in the business of selling cakes and vegetables, and she is requesting a loan to expand her business. Rose is 32 years old and married; her husband is a peasant. She has 3 children who all go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a shop.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services. These programs are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.name: Haibutllah

texts.en:
Haibutllah is 23 years old, married, and lives in Ningarhar Province. He graduated from 12th class, but because of some problems he couldn't further his education. Instead, he is working on his own land as a farmer and he has animals.   


He has five children; and he has a lot of dreams for the future of the children. Because the income of a farmer is not enough for his living expenses, he wants to buy necessary things for the land to increase his income. 


So he contacted AFSG and he requested to take 50,000 AF as a loan for 27 months. He wants to buy seeds and other essential equipment for his land to increase his production and sell it easily in the bazaar. He thanks the lenders through AFSG  for helping poor people.

loans.use: Buying more seeds for his land

texts.ru: Клиент Каримов Абдугафор проживаюший в районе Руми, в возрасте 58 лет, женат имеет двух детей.Дети клиента работают на стройки. Образования высшее, по специальности Доктор.Клиент занимается животноводством стаж клиента более 25 лет. Клиент на полученные деньги,хочет купить крупнорогатый скот для дольнейшей продажи.
texts.en:
Abdugafor K. lives in the Rumi district, is 58 years old, and is married and the father of two children. The children are construction workers. He has a higher education and is a doctor by training. He practices animal husbandry and has over 25 years of experience. He wants to use the loan to buy cattle for future sale.

Translated from Russian by Anna Brown, Kiva Volunteer

loans.name: Stella

texts.en:
Stella L. is currently in the business of selling alcohol, and she is requesting a loan to expand her business. Stella is 30 years old and married; her husband is a clerk in UNDP . She has four children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house for rental purposes.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services. These programs are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To build a house for rental purposes

texts.en:
Tofiq Z. is 54-year-old man who likes to make his own way. He runs a clothing business, which is how he supports his family, including his wife and seven children. Little by little and with hard work during more than 20 years, his business has expanded. Still, Tofiq wants his business to grow even more.

For this reason he is requesting a loan of 1200 USD, which he will pay back in 15 months. With the money, Tofiq will buy more merchandise. This way he will have new products to offer to his customers. With your help, Tofiq will be able to establish himself, save money, expand his business, and support his family. Tofiq has a good loan history; he has received one previous loan from Kiva, which he successfully completed.

Tabu A. is currently in the business of selling cakes and bread, and she is requesting a loan to expand her business. Tabu is 27 years old and is married to a business man. She has two children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a shop.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services. These programs are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.name: Harriet's Group

texts.en:
N. Harriet is the leader of Mutai group in Jinja. She is a married lady with a charcoal selling business. She sells both as a wholesaler and a retailer. She buys the charcoal from the forests, loads the lorry, and takes the charcoal to her shack, where she stores it. Since most of her customers buy in small gallons, she is able to make a weekly profit of 30,000 Ushs. As a result, she has been able to buy herself a plot of land and pay fees for her children.

Harriet needs a loan to be able to buy more charcoal for her business. Once she has access to money and more savings, she plans to construct rental houses as well as to expand her business to include firewood for sale.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal to sell

loans.name: Farkhad

texts.en:
Farkhad A. is 46 years old. He is married with two adorable sons. Farkhad is a vendor in the central local market. He sells dishes and plates of the Oriental style, along with electrical items such as irons, kettles, mixers, and so on. Farkhad has been in this business for eight years already, and his business is successful enough to enable him to support his family and his parents. Because his wife is currently unemployed, Farkhad's business generates the main income.

Now Farkhad is planning to increase his stock by purchasing dishes and plates wholesale. This products are very popular. With this purpose in mind, he is requesting 1200 USD for a term of 15 months. Farkhad thanks everyone for supporting him and promises to repay the loan on time.

loans.use: To purchase dishes and plates to sell

texts.en:
Suzi S. is currently in the business of selling bread, and she is requesting a loan to expand her business. Suzi is 39 years old and married to a business man. She has four children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a shop.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services. These programs are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

texts.ru: Клиент Азизов Бозор проживающий в районе А-Чоми,Клиенту 51 год.Женат имеет 8 детей высшего образования не имеет. Сам клиент занимается живодноводством уже более 22 -ух лет, в этом виде деятельности ему помогают сыновья.Клиент на полученные деньги хочет купить несколько бычков, для дольнейшей перепродажи.
texts.en:
Bozor A. lives in the Abdurahmoni Jomi district. He is 51 years old, married, and has eight children. He has no higher education. This client has practiced animal husbandry for over 22 years, and his sons help in the work. He wants to use the loan money to buy a few bull calves for resale in the future.

Translated from Russian by Anna Brown, Kiva Volunteer

Delgermaa B. is a micro-entrepreneur who lives with her mother in Hentiy, which is one of Mongolia's southern provinces and the homeland of Chinggis Khan, the most celebrated Mongolian of all time. In 2005, together with her mother, she began to run a bread-sales business. Her mother bakes bread at home and Delgermaa sells it at her small booth in the local market.

To expand this tiny business, in 2007 Delgermaa took a loan with XacBank, Kiva's partner microfinance institution in Mongolia. With the help of the loan, she began to sell many small items, such as instant noodle soup, biscuits and cookies, at her booth. With her profit she bought a bigger oven, allowing her mother to bake more bread. The mother-daughter team now distributes some of the bread to local grocery stores. All their bread sells out every day, as the bread is very delicious. Delgermaa is locally respected for her business and for her friendly, hard-working personality.

With this loan, Delgermaa will invest in her business and buy flour. She says, in Mongolian, "I'm planning to have my own bakery in near future."

Susan A. is currently in the business of selling alcohol, and she is requesting a loan to expand her business. Susan is 25 years old and married; her husband is a peasant . She has one child and her child does not go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a shop.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services. These programs are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

Enh-Amgalan G. is a married man who lives with his family in Hentiy, one of Mongolia's southern provinces. During the last 10 years, he has been running a furniture business. He makes doors for "gers" (Mongolian traditional nomadic housing), tables, beds, iron stoves and stove chimneys. There is high demand for these products as many Mongolians continue to live in traditional gers, heating them with small coal stoves against the frigid winter nights. He has many repeat customers as his furniture is well built. With his profits from the last 10 years, he has purchased his own plot of land, bought new furniture for his home and purchased a motorcycle. Since he needs more room for his business, he is planning to build a store this year on the land he owns. "My life condition is well improved because of my business success. My wife and I are planning to have our own big house in the future," Enh-Amgalan said in Mongolian.

loans.name: Mirqiyas

texts.en:
Mirqiyas K. is thirty-six years old and married with two children. He sells eggs from his own small chicken factory. His product is very popular and all shop vendors purchase eggs from his factory. Mirqiyas has been in this business for twelve years. During that time he has become an expert in this area and has a lot of customers. Because demand is high, the business is very successful and brings in steady and significant income, allowing Mirqiyas to improve his family's living conditions. 

Now Mirqiyas has a big order for eggs from different regions near his own city, and he needs $1200 to purchase the modern technology to expand his business. A previous loan was managed by Mirqiyas without violation, and he promises to repay the current one on time as well. He is counting on your help and expresses his gratitude to everyone supporting him.

loans.use: purchase modern technologies to expand his factory

loans.name: Yashar

texts.en: Yashar K. is a successful father of four children and a dedicated husband. Yashar began a small grocery store more than ten years ago with a small amount of savings. He is aided by his wife who helps him serve his customers. Today his clientele has grown larger and his grocery is more popular. He is asking for a loan of $1200 so that he can expand the variety of goods that are sold in his store. Yashar is very grateful to everyone who is helping him achieve success in his business with this loan.

loans.use: purchase more goods for grocery store

texts.en:
Mary Joy and Donald A. are a young couple who live in Barangay Tuao North, Bagabag, Nueva Vizcaya with their three-year-old son named Owen Harley A.. The couple plans to have a small family. Considering their minimal income resources, they want to be able to meet the children's needs as they grow. The couple want to have a well developed and sustainable business to provide their children with a good education, so they will not be like them who, unfortunately, did not pursue their studies due to financial problems.

Mary Joy is trying her best to develop her barbecue vending business, while her husband works patiently in their inherited farm lot. Donald is sometimes hired as a carpenter in their village, especially when he is not busy with his farming. At their very young age, Mary Joy and Donald show their perseverance in succeeding for the welfare of their new family. With the income from her business, Mary Joy can help her husband provide a livelihood. 

They want to increase their income in order to build their own house in the future. Mary Joy is applying for a loan of $225 to be used in the improvement of her barbecue vending business, the savings to be put toward their house construction and the education of their children. They are very thankful that they found a microfinance organization that will help them reach their goals.

loans.name: Lilian

texts.en:
Lilian J. is currently in the business of selling tomatoes and is requesting a loan to expand her business. Lilian is thirty-seven years old and is married with a husband who is a peasant-farmer. She has four children who all go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, Lilian hopes to continue to be able to pay school fees for her children.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted toward returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: pay school fees for her children

loans.name: Susan

texts.en: Susan C., who is thirty-one years old, has been a wholesaler-retailer of vegetables in Poblacion, Quezon for five years. Her husband assists Susan with the purchases of vegetables in Valencia, utilizing their motorcycle at least three times a week. With their personal capital plus the financial assistance of HSPFI, the couple would be able to sustain the project. Susan is requesting additional loan assistance from HSPFI in the amount of $325, which they will use to purchase more vegetables. Susan's long time goal is to own a 4-wheel-drive vehicle for delivering their goods to the nearby settlements.

loans.use: To purchase volume of assorted vegetables for sale

loans.name: Eldar

texts.en:
Eldar M. is a successful father and dedicated husband. He has one son who is studying in elementary school. Eldar began a small grocery store more than ten years ago with savings which he earned as a carpenter as his small capital. He was assisted by his wife who helps him with serving his customers. Today his clientele has grown greater and his grocery has become more popular. He is asking for a loan so that he may expand the variety of goods that are sold in his store.

Eldar is very grateful to everyone who helps him to achieve success in his business with this loan.

loans.use: To purchase more food goods for his store.

texts.ru: Клиент Шомахмадов Таварали проживающий в районе А_Руми, в возрасте 53 -ех лет, женат имеет 8 детей, образования среднее.Сам клиент  не где  работает, он занимается животноводством более 16 лет. У него имеется несколько бычков.На получившие деньги клиент хочет преобрести несколько молодых бычков, с дольнейшей перепродажи.
texts.en:
Tavarali S. is a client who lives in the A-Rumi region. He is 53 years old, married and has eight children. He has secondary education. He does not have a job and runs an animal husbandry business for more than sixteen years. He has several calves. He will use the loan money to buy a few more young calves for future resale.

Translated from Russian by Elena Fedorchuk, Kiva Volunteer

A mother of diligence and perseverance is Rosechelle M.. She is 30 years old and married to Rancy, a company driver. She and her husband are helping one another in improving their way of living. They have one child named Aljin, 8 years old and an elementary student. They are peacefully and happily living in Bolinao, Aurora, Isabela.

Rosechell started a village store last year. She is selling different basic commodities that are needed in every household and her store is located in front of their house. She usually earns an average weekly income of 400 pesos (about $US8). She plans to acquire more products so she can increase her income, however, she does not have enough capital to do so. She has been encouraged to request a loan amount of 5,000 pesos to further improve her business.

Amelia S. is married to Romeo S.. They are both 46 years old. They live happily in a rural place located at Barangay Tuao North, Bagabag, Nueva Vizcaya. They are blessed with two children who are presently studying in the elementary level of education. As parents, it is their responsibility to send their children to school, hence, they need to work hard in order to provide the school needs of their children.

The common source of their income is through woodcraft or furniture making of tables, cabinets, 'sala' sets and other types of furniture. In the business they manage, the couple earn a net income of only 400 pesos weekly (roughly $US8) because they pay hired workers in the shop who help in making furniture for sale. The couple plans to improve their business in order to increase their income and also to help other unemployed workers out with educational attainment to support their families, too. However, the couple lacks the needed capital.

Learning about ASKI, the micro-finance institution providing the loan, Amelia came to realize that their plans are possible. She applied for a loan of 10,000 pesos for their furniture business. She is so glad for this opportunity and hopes for the progress of her business.

Roselyn S. is newly married to Marlo S., and they live in Barangay Banganan, Aritao, Nueva Vizcaya. They were both undergraduates in high school, leaving because of financial difficulties. They work hard and strive harder in order to earn a living for their future children so they will be able to afford to send them to school until college.

Due to their low educational attainment, the couple ended up being simple farmers. Sometimes her husband works as a part-time carpenter in their village. They help each other in maintaining their onion and rice farming to yield a good harvest.They plant and harvest twice a year and they only gain a net income of 6,000 pesos (roughly $US140) per harvest season - a small amount to sustain their needs for half of the year. Their incapability in terms of financial aspects motivates Roselyn to request a loan amount of 5,000 pesos that will be used in purchasing the needed agricultural supply for their rice and onion plants.

Hard works and patience are the best ways to become successful, says Roselyn.

loans.name: Lorna

texts.en:
Lorna and her husband Noel C. lived in Barangay Banganan, Aritao, Nueva Vizcaya, together with their four children namely, Kathleen Mae, 15 years old, Krisha Mae, 12 years old, Ian, 10 years old and Kevin, 6 years old. The two eldest children are in secondary education while the other two are studying in the elementary school. The couple's greatest desire is to give their children the best education they need, because they know that it is the only treasure they can give to their children. Despite financial difficulty, they still have the courage to work hard for the welfare of their children.

Lorna and Noel are simple farmers in Barangay Banganan trying their best to overcome life's difficulties. They help each other in their planting of onions, their only source of income to support the needs in the family. They want to plant more onions in order to increase their income, so Lorna decided to find additional capital to turn their plan into reality. She is requesting a loan amount of 5,000 pesos to use in purchasing insecticide, fertilizers and other agricultural supplies they needed.

loans.use: To buy insecticides, fertilizers and farm supplies.

texts.en:
Elniyaz F. is 49 years old and married with two children. As an aspiring and hard-working man, he has always dreamed of achieving success in whatever he does. He has been dedicated to cattle farming for the past 20 years, and has vast experience in the field, as it is his only business.

This work is satisfying, and it enables Elniyaz to purchase goods for his home. He provides the markets with meat and his family with the necessary food.

Given this loan, Elniyaz will purchase young cattle and feed for them to expand his business. He plans to use the profits from his business to educate his children, improve the structure of his home and improve the standard of living of his family.

loans.name: Nhem

texts.en:
Nhem B., 47, is a villager living in the Kampong Chhnang Province in Cambodia, where he has established a family with six members. They live in a small wooden house. He currently makes a daily income to help support his family by working as a construction worker.

He is married to Em, 43, who is a local rice farmer. The couple has four children: three of them are single and the other one is married. One of their daughters is employed as a garment worker. To earn extra income, B. is applying for a $100 loan in order to buy a piglet to raise. (Mr. B.'s wife and his daughter are pictured.)

loans.use: To buy a piglet to raise

texts.en:
Emeliana F. grows rice for a living. She is 41 years old and has 6 children. She wants to increase the size of her farm so that she could have more rice to sell. She wants her children to graduate from college so that when they are older they could find a better job to support their future families. Aside from rice, she also grows vegetables in her backyard. She takes good care of her crops every day and the harvest is what she uses to buy their other needs.

She is asking for a loan of Php 8,000 from CEVI. She will use the loan to buy fertilizers and seeds. Some of the loan, she will also use to buy vegetable seeds and start other line of business.

CEVI is a non-profit organization and a partner of WorldVision Philippines that helps people start up and run their own businesses. They not only provide credit but training and insurance coverage for the clients as well.

Nurali I. is a 49-year-old farmer who lives with his wife and three children. He lives in the southern part of Azerbaijan, in the Bilasuvar Internally Displaced People Settlement. He has three calves and sells them for meat products to local traders and others.

He has 13 years of experience in raising cattle and selling them. The meat is in very high demand in his village. Nurali’s orders for meat products are very high but the number of calves is not enough for the traders, so he decided to apply for a $1,200 loan to purchase an additional three baby calves. Nurali is very grateful to everyone who is helping him to improve his life with this loan.

loans.name: Vilma

texts.en:
Having her hopes and dreams in life, Vilma was very determined to do everything for her family. She is now 41 years old and married to Roberto, who is 44 years old and works as a tricycle driver and at the same time manages their farm lot. They have three children: Rubelyn - 22 years old, Vinalyn - 21 years old and Roberto - 18 years old. None of their children have earned a college degree due to lack of money.
