Today, she teaches prospective consultants how to sell Oriflame products. She has subscribed 1,500 consultants under her license (her earnings are based on the number of consultant subscriptions.) In the future, she hopes to have her own beauty salon and to invest in her children's higher education. She has requested a loan to buy a computer, a projector and some furniture to equip her teaching room.

loans.use: To buy a computer, a projector and some furniture

loans.name: Yay

texts.en:
Mr. B. uses a trailer-cart to transport the charcoal he sells. He has been selling charcoal for more than nine years, earning income of about $3.66 each day. Mr. B. is married and the father of five teenage children who attend school. His wife, SiLeun, is 43 years old and a local vegetable planter.

Mr. B.'s business currently is doing well, and he has gained more income. Recently, he has needed capital for his business operation, so he is seeking a loan to buy additional charcoal to sell. Mr. B. is a responsible man to his family, and has supplied all they need. He is seeking to ensure that his children get the best education possible for the future. The family lives in Siem Reap Province, Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy additional charcoal to sell

texts.en: Mrs. Esterlita L., 46 years of age, is married and a resident of Roxas, Zambo Norte.  Her husband is a farmer and the family is blessed with 2 children, one still in school.  She has been an active member of Paglaum MPC for 2 years and already availed herself of 5 loans.  Now she is requesting a loan to purchase additional pigs and feed. She said that this is to supplemnet her husband's small income.  Out of their hard work and sacrifices, she's hoping that her family will have a brighter future.

K. Rokiya has been an active client of MicroInvest since 2003. She started the business practically from scratch but thanks to previous loans she opened a specialized trade outlet for selling flowers. Rokiyahas been engaged in flower selling for 12 years. Rokiya asks KIVA for a business development loan of 4100 STJ to import gifts which will permit her to expand her existing assortment and increase her business turnover.

Zainullahbudin, 51, son of Jalaludin, is married and the father of seven children.  He has been living in Khewa of Nangrahar province for a long time.  Zainullahbudin is an educated man and the governor of a district of Khewa, who works in agriculture on his won land.
  
He has a lot of experience in agriculture.  Now Zainullahbudin wants to buy animals for his land to sell milk and yogurt in the bazaar.  Because of the expense he want to increase his income.  Therefore he requested an individual 50000AF (1,075US) loan.

He would like to thank all lenders, Kiva and AFSG in Jalalabad, Afghanistan.  They support poor people in the poor countries.

V., 26, is a widowed mother who has two children. Both of her children are still young and she cares for them. The family lives in Pursat Province, Cambodia. V. sells grocery items in the village and raises pigs in a stall next to her house. Pig raising is V.'s main source of income. Right now, her pigs are mature enough for slaughter.  Therefore, she is requesting a loan of $300 to buy pigs to raise.

texts.ru: Раджабова Нурбиби проживает в районе Гиссар. Возраст 32 года , замужем и имеет двоих детей. Муж в России на заработках. Но  у него с работой проблемы в данный момент. Поэтому Нурбиби одна занимается обеспечением семьи. Уже около восьми лет она работает в столовой "Вохури".столовая находится на центральном рынке и дает неплохой доход. Сейчас Нурбиби планирует получить кредит для того, чтобы закупить новый инвентарь. Это поможет улучшить качество обслуживания и привлечь новых клиентов. Погасить кердит планирует в течение 12 месяцев.
texts.en:
Nurbibi R. lives in the Gissar district. She is 32 years, married and has two children. Her husband is currently working in Russia; however he is having problems with work. This is why Nurbibi is now the sole provider for her family. For almost eight years, she has been working at the Vohuri cafeteria. The cafeteria is located in the central market and brings in a decent income. Currently, Nurbibi plans to obtain a loan in order to purchase new inventory. This will help her improve the quality of service and attract new clients. She plans to repay this loan within 12 months.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

texts.ru: Рахмонова Хусния проживает в районе Гиссар. Возраст 28 лет, незамужем . Живет с родителями. Уже около восьми лет занимается торговлей. Имеет магазин по продаже продуктов питания . Магазин имеет своих клиентов , но Хусния хочет увеличить ассортимент товара , который позволит ей привлечь новых клиентов. Для этого в данный момент она планирует получить кредит , сроком на 12 месяцев.
texts.en:
Husniya R. lives in the Gissar region. She is 28 years old, not married. She lives with parents. She has been in the retail business for about eight years. She has a store where she sells food. Husniya has many customers, but wants to increase the variety of goods which will in turn attract new customers. For this she plans to get a loan for a 12 months term.

Translated from Russian by Elena Fedorchuk, Kiva Volunteer

loans.name: Vong

texts.en:
C., 46, is a widowed mother of three children.  The children attend school.  The family lives in Pursat Province. 

C. makes a daily income by selling fish at the local market. As another income source, she raises pigs at her house.  The pigs mature in four months at which point she sells them to be slaughtered. C.'s investment in raising pigs is running smoothly and provides her with a lot of income.  She is requesting a loan of $200 to buy another piglet to raise.

loans.use: to buy another piglet to raise

loans.name: Florence's Group

texts.en:
Florence has a small restaurant business.  She prepares local foods like matoke (a steamed mashed banana dish), posho (a maize flour and water dish), meat stew, fish stew, and rice and beans.  Florence is requesting a loan of 500,000 USH to expand her restaurant in significant ways.  First, she would like to purchase more chairs to increase the number of customers she can cater too.  Second, she would like to sell the small refrigerator that she recently purchased, and use the money from the sale in conjunction with a portion of her loan to purchase a larger refrigerator.  She explained that in the restaurant business, having a larger refrigerator really increases profits because it allows one to sell cold sodas and keep foodstuffs for longer periods of time.    

Florence was recently widowed.  She was left with one child of her own and three other children to care for.  All of the children are in school, but she only pays school fees for her own child.  Another individual aids the other three. She knows that it is very important to expand her business right now as she is now the sole provider for these children.

loans.use: to purchase chairs and a large refrigerator for her restaurant.

loans.name: Marie

texts.fr:
H. Marie est née vers 1955 à Abomey. Marie vit à Porto-Novo, capitale administrative et politique du Bénin. Marie est mariée et mère de trois(3) enfants. Marie est une vendeuse de «monyo», pâte local à base de maïs, accompagnée de sauce de tomate. Cette activité que Marie mène avec  beaucoup de passion lui procure de revenus qui lui permettent de faire face à ses besoins et à ceux sa famille. Pour renforcer le niveau de son activité économique Marie exprime un besoin de crédit.  
 
La signification de ALIDé en langue locale du Bénin, le Fon, est « un chemin existe toujours pour les plus pauvres ». Le Bénin est un petit pays de l’Afrique de l’Ouest à coté du Nigeria où le PIB par habitant est à $1,500. ALIDé offre les prêts spéciaux de 0% d’intérêt aux personnes très vulnérables et elle est dans un groupe qui lance bientôt un programme de la micro-assurance santé pour les bénéficiaires de micro crédit.
texts.en:
H. Marie was born around 1955 in Abomey. She lives in Porto-Novo, the administrative and political capital of Bénin, and is the married mother of three children. Marie sells "monyo", a local mash made from corn and accompanied by tomato sauce. This work that Maria performs with passion brings her the revenue enabling her to address her needs and those of her family. To bolster her level of commerce, she is expressing a need for a loan.

Alidé means “there is always a path for the poorest” in Benin’s local language of Fon. Benin is a small West African country located next to Nigeria and has a per capita GDP of $1,500. Alidé offers special loans to highly vulnerable people at an interest rate of 0%. It is part of a group that is soon launching a micro health insurance program for recipients of micro-loans.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy corn and condiments: tomatoes, chili peppers, fish, meat, onions, spices, etc.

texts.fr:
D. Josephine est née vers 1979 à Ahoumbo dans la Commune de SAKETE, département de Plateau. D. Josephine est mariée et mère d'un enfant scolarisé. Depuis 25ans, Josephine transforme le noix de palme en ses différents produits finis (huile rouge, boisson locale alcoolisée,appelée ici "sodabi" ,etc.)qu'elle commercialise. Josephine a besoin de moyens financiers pour développer son activité à la mesure de ses expériences.

 
La signification de ALIDé en langue locale du Bénin, le Fon, est « un chemin existe toujours pour les plus pauvres ». Le Bénin est un petit pays de l’Afrique de l’Ouest à coté du Nigeria où le PIB par habitant est à $1,500. ALIDé offre les prêts spéciaux de 0% d’intérêt aux personnes très vulnérables et elle est dans un groupe qui lance bientôt un programme de la micro-assurance santé pour les bénéficiaires de micro crédit.
texts.en:
D. Josephine was born around 1979 in Ahoumbo, in SAKETE Commune, Plateau County. She is married and the mother of on child, who is in school. For 25 years, she has been processing palm nuts into her different finished products (red oil, a local alcoholic drink, called "sodabi" etc.) that she markets. She is in need of financial support to develop her business to the level of her experience. Alidé means “there is always a path for the poorest” in Benin’s local language of Fon. Benin is a small West African country located next to Nigeria and has a per capita GDP of $1,500. Alidé offers special loans to highly vulnerable people at an interest rate of 0%. It is part of a group that is soon launching a micro health insurance program for recipients of micro-loans.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.name: Shakira's Group

texts.en:
Nabateregga Shakira is the leader of the Namungoona loan group in Kampala. She is a married lady with no children.  She has a business of selling television sets, electronics, phones, and electronic accessories from Bakuli, Mengo. Her profits help pay for school fees for her two brothers that she helps to care for.

This is the third time Shakira is seeking a loan from Pearl Microfinance. The first two loans helped her so much in enlarging her shop by allowing her to sell phones that she did not have before. She is requesting this loan so that she can buy more phones and DVDs to sell.

loans.use: to buying more phones and DVDs to sell

texts.vi:
Chị D. 35 tuổi hiện đang sống cùng chồng và 3 con tại huyện Mê Linh - Hà Nội. Chị D. tham gia Quỹ tình thương từ năm 2002 với nghề chính là chăn nuôi. Hiện tại ngoài chăn nuôi chị D. còn đầu tư vốn để buôn bán rau. Với mức thu nhập 5.000.000đ/ tháng gia đình chị D. đang ngày càng có thêm điều kiện để cải thiện cuộc sống.
Vòng vốn tới chị D. mong muốn được vay 20.000.000đ để đầu tư mua lợn về nuôi và đầu tư thêm vốn để buôn bán rau.
texts.en:
Mrs. D. is 35 years old, and is living with her husband and three children at Me Linh District, Hanoi. She joined TYM Fund in 2002 to invest in her livestock raising business. Besides raising, Mrs. D. also invest her loans in selling vegetables. At an income of 5,000,000 VND per month, Mrs. D. and her family has more opportunity to improve their living standard. She would like to borrow 20,000,000 VND to invest in more pigs to raise and to invest in her vegetables business.

Translated from Vietnamese by Thiennga Ngo, Kiva Volunteer

texts.fr:
Djénèba B. a 41 ans et vit dans une grande famille avec son époux et ses  5 enfants ( 3 garçons et 2 filles) plus 8 enfants adoptifs à Hamdallaye, un des  quartiers populaires de la ville de Sikasso  (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
N’ayant pas eu la chance de faire une longue étude, elle s’est initiée à  l’activité d’achat et de vente de tubercules (Pomme de terre, patate, igname, etc) il y a environ vingt 20 ans. Elle mène son activité au nouveau marché du quartier  Médine de la ville de Sikasso où elle est très appréciée et sollicitée de beaucoup de clients. 
Dans le souci de mieux satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, elle décida de rejoindre l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso il y a maintenant 4 ans. Après 2 prêts solidaires (prêt de groupe) dans une association des femmes de son quartier, elle est à son premier prêt individuel.. 
Elle compte acheter avec ce prêt, 24 sacs de pomme de terre en gros sur place auprès des agriculteurs venant à la foire. Elle effectue sa vente en détail, au comptant à une clientèle constituée d’hommes et de femmes.
Elle envisage réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel de 100 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour augmenter son fonds de commerce, contribuer aux dépenses familiales, rembourser les intérêts du prêt et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en:
Djénèba B. is 41 years old and lives in a large family with her husband and five children (three boys and two girls), plus eight adopted children, in Hamdallaye, a busy neighborhood in the town of Sikasso (the Republic of Mali's third administrative region). Not having had the opportunity for much schooling, she became involved in buying and selling root vegetables (potatoes, sweet potatoes, yams, etc.) about 20 years ago. She runs her business at the new market in Sikasso’s Médine neighborhood, where she is very popular and much in demand by many customers. Keen to better satisfy her ever-growing clientele, she decided to join the Soro Yiriwaso microfinance institution four years ago. After two solidarity loans (group loans) as part of a women’s association from her neighborhood, she is now on her first individual loan. She plans to use this loan to buy 24 bags of potatoes locally at wholesale from growers who come to the market. She sells at retail for cash to a clientele consisting of both men and women. She expects to make a monthly profit of CFA 100,000 which will mainly be used to increase her working capital, contribute towards the family expenses and pay the interest on the loan. The remainder will be invested in the business.

Translated from French by Sarah Llewellyn, Kiva Volunteer

loans.name: 03-Đông Sơn Group

texts.en:
Group 03 - Đông Sơn is made up of five women from the Đông Sơn commune in Thanh Hoa City, approximately 150 km south of Hanoi.  
 
* Ms. Lê Thị Thảo is the group leader and was born in 1957.  Her husband, Mr. Đỗ Văn Dung, was born in 1953 and works as a professional home painter.  They have four children, two daughters and two sons.  Her two daughters are married and both of her sons work full time, one in construction and one in painting like his father.  Ms. Thảo used her previous loans from the Fund for Thanh Hoa Poor Women to invest in vegetables and fish for resale.  With this loan, she plans to continue investing in her vegetable and fish business but hopes to use a portion of her loan to diversify and begin raising chickens.  This is her fourth loan from FPW and she is borrowing 6.000.000 VND (~$340 USD) with a loan term of two years. 

The other members in the group are also each borrowing 6.000.000 VND (~$340 USD).
* Ms. Ngô Thị Hạnh is 40 years old and plans to invest in her fish and vegetable resale business.
* Ms. T. Thị Loan will use her funds to purchase a cargo-bicycle to offer transport services for people wishing to move heavy items.
* Ms. Lê Thị Mùi wishes to use her loan to invest in her breakfast store specializing in bánh cuốn (ground pork and mushrooms rolled in a thin rice sheet), a specialty in Northern Viet Nam. 
* Ms. Đỗ Thị Nho is borrowing to invest in her drink sales business.


-----------------------------------------

*Phường Đông Sơn thuộc thành phố Thanh Hóa, tỉnh Thanh Hóa . Tỉnh Thanh Hóa cách Hà Nội 150km về phía Nam. Nhóm 03 ở phố 5 thuộc phường Đông Sơn có 5 thành viên ,chị Lê Thị Thảo làm nhóm trưởng, chị sinh năm 1957, chồng chị là Đỗ Văn Dung, sinh năm 1953,làm nghề thợ sơn. Gia đình chị có 4 người con ,2 con gái đầu đã lập gia đình,1 con trai làm nghề xây dựng,1 con trai làm nghề sơn. Các kỳ trước chị vay vốn về để buôn rau và cá, kỳ này chị vay vồn để mở rộng thêm hàng rau và mua thêm gà về nuôi. Chị đang vay chu kỳ 4 ,mức vay là 6.000.000VNĐ (~340 USD), thời hạn vay là 2 năm .Các thành viên khác trong nhóm có cùng mức vay như chị.
*Chị Ngô Thị Hạnh năm nay 40 tuổi,chị vay vốn để buôn bán cá và rau.
*Chị Đỗ Thị Nho vay vốn để bán hàng giải khát.
*Chị T. Thị Loan vay vốn để mua xe ba gác về chở hàng thuê..
*Chị Lê Thị Mùi vay vốn về để đầu tư hàng bánh cuốn sáng.

loans.use: to invest in food and drinks for resale, a cargo-bicycle and restaurant businesses.

texts.vi: Chị Đỗ Thị Chỉ, năm nay 35 tuổi ở Mê Linh, Hà Nội. Anh chị có ba con nhỏ và hiện đều đang đi học. Chị tham gia Quỹ từ năm 2002 với hoạt động chính là chăn nuôi, buôn bán rau  và tiền công làm thợ xây của chồng. Hiện tại thu nhập bình quân của gia đình chị 5.000.000/tháng. Vòng vốn tới anh chị mong muốn được vay thêm 20.000.000  một phần gia đình chị sử dụng để đầu tư mua bò về nuôi, phần còn lại chị sử dụng đầu tư thêm vốn để buôn bán rau.
texts.en:
Mrs. Do Thi C. is 35 years old, living in Me Linh, Hanoi. She and her husband has three young children who are going to school. She joined TYM Fund in 2002. Her main source of income comes from livestock raising, selling vegetables and her husband's salary as a construction worker. Currently, her average income grosses at 5,000,000 VND per month. She would like to borrow 20,000,000 VND to invest in buying cows and in her vegetable selling business.

Translated from Vietnamese by Thiennga Ngo, Kiva Volunteer

texts.fr:
G. Cécile est née le 18 février 1975 dans la commune d'ifangni à Sakété,département de Plateau. G. Cécile est mariée et mère de  02 enfants dont 01 est scolarisé. Cécile vit actuellement avec son mari à Takon dans la commune de Sakété, département de Plateau. Cécile est une vendeuse d'huile rouge  qu'elle obtient après transformation de noix de palme. Faute de moyens financiers, Cécile n'a pas encore pu développer son activité. C'est pourquoi Cécile demande un prêt pour y arriver.
 
La signification de ALIDé en langue locale du Bénin, le Fon, est « un chemin existe toujours pour les plus pauvres ». Le Bénin est un petit pays de l’Afrique de l’Ouest à coté du Nigeria où le PIB par habitant est à $1,500. ALIDé offre les prêts spéciaux de 0% d’intérêt aux personnes très vulnérables et elle est dans un groupe qui lance bientôt un programme de la micro-assurance santé pour les bénéficiaires de micro crédit.
texts.en:
G. Cécile was born on February 18, 1975 in the commune of Ifangni in Sakété, Plateau County. She is married and the mother of two children, one of whom is in school. She currently lives with her husband in Takon in the commune of Sakété, Plateau County. Cécile is a retailer of red oil, which she obtains from processing palm nuts. Lacking financial means, she has not been able to develop her business. This is why she's asking for a loan.

Alidé means “there is always a path for the poorest” in Benin’s local language of Fon. Benin is a small West African country located next to Nigeria and has a per capita GDP of $1,500. Alidé offers special loans to highly vulnerable people at an interest rate of 0%. It is part of a group that is soon launching a micro health insurance program for recipients of micro-loans.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

texts.vi: Chị Đỗ Thị Hậu, 47 tuổi, sống ở Mê Linh - Hà Nội. Các con của chị đều đã lớn và đã đi làm để phụ giúp gia đình. Chị tham gia Quỹ từ năm 2002, với số vay được chị đầu tư mở rộng chăn nuôi lợn, bò. Với việc chăn nuôi hiệu quả và sự hỗ trợ thêm hàng tháng của các con hiện nay thu nhập bình quân của gia đình là 6.000.000/ tháng. Vòng vay tới chị mong muốn được vay thêm 20.000.000 để đầu tư mua bò về nuôi và mua  gạch đế sửa sang nhà cửa.
texts.en:
Mrs Do Thi H. is 47 years old, living in Me Linh, Ha Noi. Her children are all grown and work to support the family. She joined TYM Fund in 2002. With her loans, she invested in expanding her livestock raising business. With a successful business and her children's financial help, her family's income grosses at 6,000,000 VND per month. She would like to borrow 20,000,000 VND to invest in buying more cows and bricks for home improvement.

Translated from Vietnamese by Thiennga Ngo, Kiva Volunteer

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe Lafia (composé de 6 femmes mariées et d’une veuve) avec une moyenne d’âge de 46 ans, 4 enfants  vivent dans des  familles polygames à Kamalen Sirakoro un des villages de la commune de Sikasso  3ème région administrative  de la république du Mali. .
Elles mènent diverses  activités  qui sont entre autres la vente de tasses, de tissus, d’arachide, de charbon de bois, de la pomme de terre, de tomates et des condiments alimentaires.
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle et sont à leur dixième  prêt solidaire (prêt de groupe). Tous les prêts précédents ont été correctement remboursés
Avec ce nouveau prêt, elles comptent acheter 50 paniers de tomates, 8 douzaines de tasses en plastiques et aluminiums , 5 sacs de 100 kg de pomme de terre, 3 colis de condiments, 10 rouleaux de tissus et 50 sacs de 100 kg de charbon de bois. Elles s’approvisionnent dans les voisinages du village de kamalen Sirakoro, au marché de Médine et au grand marché de Sikasso . 
Les marchandises sont vendues  au comptant en détail et à crédit  au marché de Kamalen Sirakoro, dans les concessions de (façon ambulante) et dans  les villages environnants à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. 
 Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 14.250FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée pour les besoins de la famille et l’autre partie sera investie dans les activités.
Les femmes du groupe Lafia ambitionnent être des grossistes.
texts.en:
The members of the Lafia group (composed of six married women and one widow) have an average age of 46 and four children, and live in polygamous families in Kamalen Sirakoro, one of the villages in the district of Sikasso, the Republic of Mali’s third administrative region. They run various businesses including the sale of cups, cloth, peanuts, charcoal, potatoes, tomatoes and spices. They are working with the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso in order to meet the needs of their clientele and are on their 10th solidarity loan (group loan). All previous loans were fully repaid. With this new loan, they plan to buy 50 baskets of tomatoes, eight dozen plastic and aluminum cups, five 100-kg bags of potatoes, three boxes of spices, 10 bolts of fabric and 50 100-kg bags of charcoal. They obtain their supplies from Kamalen Sirakoro's surrounding area, the market at Médine and the main market in Sikasso. They retail their products for cash or credit at the market in Kamalen Sirakoro, by walking around stalls, and in local villages to a clientele consisting of both men and women. Each member expects to make a monthly profit of CFA 14,250, half of which will be used for the family’s needs and the other half invested in the business. The women of the Lafia group eventually want to become wholesalers.

Translated from French by Sarah Llewellyn, Kiva Volunteer

texts.vi: Chị Nguyễn Thị Cửi, 49 tuổi ở Mê Linh - Hà Nội. Anh chị có 3 con và đều đã lớn, đi làm tạo thêm thu nhập cho gia đình. Chị tham gia Quỹ từ năm 1999 với số vốn vay được anh chị đã đầu tư mở rộng chăn nuôi lợn.Bên cạnh đó chị còn làm công nhân môi trường nên hàng tháng đều có nguồn thu ổn định từ lương. Hiện nay thu nhập bình quân của gia đình chị là 5.000.000/tháng. Vòng vốn tới anh chị mong muốn được vay thêm 10.000.000 để mua thêm lợn và mua thức ăn chăn nuôi.
texts.en:
Mrs. Nguyen Thi C. is 49 years old, living in Me Linh, Ha Noi. She has three grown children who are working and supporting the family. She joined TYM Fund in 1999. With her loan, she and her husband invested in expanding her pig raising business. Additionally, she also works as a sanitation worker so her family has a stable income from her salary. Currently, her family's income grosses at 5,000,000 VND per month. She would like to borrow 10,000,000 VND to invest in buying more pigs and livestock feed.

Translated from Vietnamese by Thiennga Ngo, Kiva Volunteer

loans.name: Wofunira Development Association (B) Group

texts.en: Ruth has had her poultry business for about 5 years now.  She has 400 broiler chickens that she raises.  People come to her home and buy these chickens to take to the market to sell.    Ruth says that the market for broiler chickens is very large so it is able to support the large number of people who do it. Ruth buys her chickens from Uga-chick.  Uga-chick is a place where many Ugandan poultry farmers buy day-old chickens.  Although this practice does not differentiate her from other poultry farmers, she tries to be competitive in the market by spending extra money on food supplements.  The important thing with broiler chickens is that they are heavy.  If you just feed the chickens a lot of food, they will grow heavy, but not as heavy as if you spend a little extra for supplements.    Ruth has four older children who stay around her home.  She says that although they are now old (32, 30, 28, and 25), they still depend on her.  She also has 3 small children that she cares for.  Two of these children are from her late brother and one of them is a grandchild.  These children all need their daily needs met as well as school fees.    Ruth is requesting a loan of 250,000 USH.  This will allow her to buy the critical supplements as well as four bags of feed.

loans.use: Food for her chickens as well as supplements to make them fat.

loans.name: Mean's Group

texts.en:
K. is a leader of a group of three members. She is 52 years old and a mother of four children: the first two are married and live separately, the last two are the students. K. is a widow mother and works in the private company since 2000. She is famous for her hard work and her responsibility. With the salary, she hardly manages with the family's expenses, and she is tired of taking the motor taxi but she is good at saving money. Hence, to reduce the family's expenses, K. is taking a loan to buy a motorbike for the family's transportation.

The other two members of the group are: N., 51, who serves ingredient porridge as the breakfast meal by her house, is applying for the loan to buy fruits to sell in the night time for another income. And S., 34, who works in the private company, is requesting the loan to pay for the certificate of motor tax. They all live in Battambang Province, Cambodia.

loans.use: to buy a motorbike for the family's transportation.

texts.ru: Каримова Ибодатой проживает в Гиссарском районе. Возраст 49 лет, замужем и имеет пятерых детей. Занимается торговлей на центральном рынке. Торгует растительным , в частности хлопковым маслом. Товар завозит из города Душанбе. В данный момент возникла проблема с тем , что произошел дефицит денег . Поэтому она решила получить кредит для того, чтобы увеличить товарооборот.Погасить кредит сможет в течение 12 месяцев.
texts.en:
Ibodatoy K. lives in the Gissar region. She is 49 years old, is married and has five children. She sells products at the central market. She sells vegetable, in particular cottonseed oil. She brings her products in from Dushanbe. Right now she has a problem with a money deficit. This is why she has decided to take out a loan in order to increase her inventory. She will be able to pay back the loan over 12 months.

Translated from Russian by Sabina Holzman, Kiva Volunteer

texts.fr:
Les sept femmes du groupe Mougnou (toutes mariées) avec une moyenne d’âge de 34 ans et 3 enfants,  vivent la plupart dans des  familles polygames à Kamalen Sirakoro un des villages de la commune de Sikasso 3ème région administrative de la république du Mali. .
Elles mènent diverses  activités  qui sont entre autres la vente de poissons fumés,  frais, d’atieké, d’arachide et de chaussures.
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle et sont à leur deuxième  prêt de groupe après avoir correctement remboursé le premier.
Avec ce  prêt, elles comptent acheter,  3 colis d’articles de boutique, 50 kg de poissons fumés, 25 kg de poissons frais,  100 kg d’atieké, 250 kg d’arachide, et 12 douzaines de paires de chaussures en plastiques.
Elles s’approvisionnent au marché de Médine et au grand marché de Sikasso.
Les marchandises sont vendues la plupart au comptant ,au marché de Kamalen Sirakoro et dans les villages avoisinants à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes.
Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 13.500FCFA  dont une partie sera épargnée et l’autre partie sera investie dans les activités.
texts.en:
The seven women in the Mougnou group (all married) have an average age of 34 and three children, and most live in polygamous families in Kamalen Sirakoro, one of the villages in the district of Sikasso, the Republic of Mali’s third administrative region. They run various businesses, including selling smoked and fresh fish, atieké cassava, peanuts and shoes. In order to meet customer needs, they are working with the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso and are on their second group loan, having successfully repaid the first one. They plan to use this loan to buy three boxes of boutique items, 50 kg of smoked fish, 25 kg of fresh fish, 100 kg of atieké, 250 kg of peanuts, and 12 dozen pairs of plastic shoes. They obtain their supplies from the market in Médine and the main market in Sikasso. Most of the goods are sold for cash at Karmalen Sirakoro’s market and in neighboring villages to a clientele composed of both men and women. Each member expects to make a monthly profit of CFA 13,500, half of which will be saved and the other half invested in the business.

Translated from French by Sarah Llewellyn, Kiva Volunteer

texts.vi: Chị Nguyễn Thị Hương , 44 tuổi ở Mê Linh - Hà Nội. Chị tham gia Quỹ từ năm 1997 và vay vốn để đầu tư vào chăn nuôi lợn . Hiện nay ngoài nguồn thu từ chăn nuôi hàng tháng gia đình chị còn có thêm nguồn thu ổn định từ lương làm thợ xây của chồng  2.000.000đ/ tháng.  Vòng vốn tới anh chị mong muốn được vay thêm 10.000.000 để mua thêm lợn và mua thức ăn phục vụ  chăn nuôi.
texts.en:
Ms. Huong Thi N. is a 44 years old woman in Me Linh, Hanoi. She joined the TYM fund in 1997 and borrowed money to raise pigs. At the moment, besides the income from the livestock, salary of 2,000,000 VND per month of her husband also contributes to the family’s budget. The couple plan to borrow 10,000,000 VND to buy more pigs and food for them.

Translated from Vietnamese by Duc Tran, Kiva Volunteer

loans.name: Asuman's Group

texts.en: K. Asuman is the leader of Namungoona group in Kampala. He is 30 years old and has a business of selling electricals, phones and phone accessories. He has had three years in his business whereby he first had it in Kisenyi suburbs and has now relocated to Bakuli, Mengo where the customer base is large enough for his business. Asuman needs a loan to buy more phones plus their accessories from the city shops and he would like to be able to buy them from Kenya where the prices are a bit favorable. He cares for 1 boy on his elder brother’s behalf since he can not cater for him at the moment. He says the secret to his business success is being able to seek advice from other friends in business as well as the use of loans from Pearl Microfinance.

loans.use: Buying more phones and phone accessories for his shop.

texts.fr:
V. Kponbogan est née dans la commune de zoungbomey le 19 septembre 1970. Actuellement Kponbogan vit à Takon à Sakété, département de Plateau. Kponbogan est mariée et mère de 03 enfants dont un seul est scolarisé. V. Kponbogan transforme le noix de palme en ses différents produits finis. Mais Kponbogan n'a pas suffisamment d'argent pour élever son niveau d'activité. Pour pouvoir y arriver, Kponbogan a besoin de crédit. 
 
La signification de ALIDé en langue locale du Bénin, le Fon, est « un chemin existe toujours pour les plus pauvres ». Le Bénin est un petit pays de l’Afrique de l’Ouest à coté du Nigeria où le PIB par habitant est à $1,500. ALIDé offre les prêts spéciaux de 0% d’intérêt aux personnes très vulnérables et elle est dans un groupe qui lance bientôt un programme de la micro-assurance santé pour les bénéficiaires de micro crédit.
texts.en:
V. Kponbogan was born in the area of zoungbomey on September 19 septembre 1970. Currently, Kponbogan lives in Takon in Sakété, a department in the Plains. Kponbogan is married and mother of 3 children, only 1 of whom is in school. V. Kponbogan transforms palm nut in its various finished products. But Kponbogan does not have sufficient funds to improve her level of activity. To accomplish this, Kponbogan needs a loan. The meaning of ALIDé in the local language of Benin, the Fon, is « a path always exists for the poorest ». Benin is a small country in West Africa next to Nigeria where the GNP per capita is $1,500. ALIDé offers special 0% loans to very vulnerable people and is part of a group that will soon launch a microinsurance program for the beneficiaries of microcredit.

Translated from French by Isabelle Barres, Kiva Volunteer

loans.name: Fahari Yetu Group

texts.en:
Saidi J., age 40, is married with five children ages 16, 13, 9, 7 and 4.  He has a garage which he started in 2000.  He works from 8am to 7pm, daily. Saidi is able to earn a monthly profit of around $336. 

This will be Said’s sixth loan from Tujijenge Tanzania.  He used the five loans to increase stock by buying spare parts, compressors and paint and has paid the loans back successfully.  He now hopes for a new loan to increase capital  and to buy more spare parts.

Said will share this loan with subgroup C of the Fahari Yetu group.  The subgroup has six members who run cafes and general stores.  These members hold each other accountable for repaying their loans.  In the picture, Said is the only man.

loans.use: Increase capital and buy more spare parts.

texts.ru: Гуломова Сохибджамол проживает в Гисаарском районе. Занимается торговлей. В сфере бизнеса работает уже 14 лет. Торгует растительным маслом на центральном рынке Гиссара. Ей 38 лет, она замужем и имеет четверых детей. Планирует получить кредит для того, чтобы увеличить товарооборот. Погасить кредит планирует в течение 12 месяцев.
texts.en:
Sohibjamol G. lives in the Gissar region. She works in sales. Sohibjamol has 14 years of experience in the business sphere. She sells vegetable oil at the central market in Gissar. Sohibjamol is 38 years old, she is married and has four children. She plans to take out a loan in order to increase her inventory. Sohibjamol plans to pay back the loan over 12 months.

Translated from Russian by Sabina Holzman, Kiva Volunteer

texts.vi:
Ch ị Lỗ Thị Đường, 44 tuổi, s ống ở M ê Linh - H à Nội cùng chồng và 3 con. Chị tham gia Quỹ từ năm 2000. Hiện nay chị  Đường đang làm nghề thu mua phế liệu  và chăn nuôi tại nhà còn anh  Thường chồng chị làm nghề say sát. Đây cũng là những công việc đem lai cho gia đình chị thu nhập 6.000.000đ/ tháng.
Vòng vốn tới chị mong muốn được vay thêm 15.000.000 để đầu tư , xây dựng lại chuồng trại mở rộng chăn nuôi.
texts.en:
Ms. Duong Thi L. is a 44 years old woman in Me Linh, Hanoi. She lives with her husband and three children. She joined the TYM fund in 2000. At the moment, Ms. Duong buys back scrap metal and raise livestock, while Mr. Thuong, her husband, grinds raw rice. All businesses bring in about 6,000,000 VND per month. Ms. Duong wants to borrow 15,000,000 VND to renovate the stable.

Translated from Vietnamese by Duc Tran, Kiva Volunteer

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe Sabali (composé de 5 femmes mariées et d’une veuve) ont une moyenne d’âge de 32 ans et 3 enfants. Elles vivent, la plupart dans des  familles traditionnelles élargies à Kamalen Sirakoro un des villages de la commune de Sikasso  3ème région administrative  de la république du Mali. 
Elles mènent diverses  activités  qui sont entre autres la vente de poissons fumés, du charbon de bois, d’arachides, de pomme de terre, tissus, chaussures, de soumbala et enfin des articles de boutique.  
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle et sont à leur huitième  prêt de groupe. Tous les prêts précédents se sont bien  dénoués.
Avec ce nouveau prêt, elles comptent acheter 65 kg de poissons fumés, 4 paquets d’articles de boutique, 600 kg de pomme de terre,  200 kg d’arachide, 30 sacs de 100 kg de charbon de bois,10 paniers de soumbala et 5 douzaines de paire de chaussures en plastique,  6 pièces de pagnes wax  real.
 Elles s’approvisionnent aux marchés (Médine et au grand marché) de Sikasso ville et  dans les  localités avoisinantes. 
Les marchandises sont vendues au marché de Kamalen Sirakoro et dans les villages avoisinants à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes et la plupart au comptant.
Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 17.000 FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée pour les besoins de la famille et l’autre partie sera investie dans les activités.
texts.en:
The members of the group Sabali are composed of five married women and one widow who average 32 years of age and 3 children each. They live for the most part in traditional extended families in Kamalen Sirakoro, a village of the Sikasso community (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). The women do a variety of work, including selling smoked fish, charcoal, peanuts, potatoes, cloth, shoes, soumbala (a condiment made from fermented pounded seeds or beans), and finally boutique items.

The women are collaborating with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso to satisfy the needs of their customers and are on their eighth group loan. All the preceding loans were settled. With this new loan, they intend to buy: 65 kg of smoked fish, four packets of boutique items, 600 kg of potatoes, 200 kg of peanuts, thirty 100-kg sacks of charcoal, ten baskets of soumbala, five dozen pairs of plastic shoes, and six bolts of Wax Real pagnes (colorful West African cloth).

Supplies are gotten at the marketplaces (in Médine and at the grand market) of Sikasso City and in neighboring towns. The goods are sold mostly in cash transactions at the Kamalen Sirakoro market and in neighboring villages. The customers are composed of men and women.

The group members each envision realizing an average monthly profit of 17,000 francs CFA. A portion of the profits will be for meeting family needs and the other portion will be invested in business.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

texts.vi: Chị Nguyễn Thị Thắm, 27 tuổi, sống ở Mê Linh - Hà Nội. Gia đình chị có 2 con nhỏ còn đang đi học. Chị tham gia Quỹ từ năm 1998 và vay vốn để đầu tư vào chăn nuôi lợn. Hiện nay bên cạnh chăn nuôi gia đình chị còn có thêm nghề làm đậu phụ. Anh Quân chồng chị ngoài thời gian phụ giúp vợ còn tranh thủ đi làm thuê để tăng thêm thu nhập cho gia đình Với mức thu nhập bình quân  5.000.000/ tháng kinh tế gia đình chị Thắnm đang ngày càng ổn định và phát triển hơn. Vòng vốn tới chị mong muốn được vay 10.000.000 để đầu tư chăn nuôi lợn và mua nguyên liệu về làm đậu bán
texts.en:
Ms. Tham Thi N. is a 27 years old woman in Me Linh, Hanoi. She has two children still going to school. Joining the TYM fund in 1998, she borrowed money to raise pigs. Besides, she also makes tofu. Her husband, Mr. Quan, is a seasonal worker. With the income of about 5,000,000 VND per month, their living condition is improving. Ms. Tham wants to borrow 10,000,000 VND to buy pigs and material to make tofu.

Translated from Vietnamese by Duc Tran, Kiva Volunteer

loans.name: Letecia

texts.en: Letecia A. is a restaurant operator whose business is located alongside the jeep terminal of her village, and has had many years of operation.  However, to date, she is the only one sustaining this project; other restaurants closed due to financial reasons. Most of her customers are drivers, neighbors and passersby. She received a loan from HSPFI amounting to PHP 14000, just enough to purchase soft drinks, meat, and ingredients for food processing. She is planning to purchase additional kitchen utensils with the next funds.

loans.use: To purchase soft drinks, meat, and ingredients

loans.name: Adiara

texts.fr:
Madame  Adiara Berthé a 54 ans et réside avec son époux et leurs 6 enfants à Sanoubougou I, un des  quartiers populaires de la ville de Sikasso (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
N’ayant pas eu la chance d’avancer à l’école pour des raisons sociales, Adiara s’est initiée dans l’activité de teinture et vente de bazins qu’elle a apprise  auprès d’une camarade il y a plus de vingt ans. Après avoir teint les bazins, elle coût quelques pièces en chemise masculine qu’elle  revend. Elle est beaucoup sollicitée de sa clientèle (composée essentiellement de voyageurs et de routiers) pour la qualité de ses produits.
Dans le souci de mieux satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, elle décida d’intégrer l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso depuis plus de six  ans. Après plusieurs prêts solidaires (prêt du groupe) dans une association des femmes de son quartier, elle est à son 9ème prêt individuel,  tous les prêts précédents ont été correctement remboursés.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          Elle compte acheter avec ce prêt 10 pièces de bazins blancs, 10 boîtes de teintures de couleurs différentes, 10 paquets de soudes caustiques et quelques pièces de pagnes wax. Elle s’approvisionne à Bamako (capitale du Mali)  et effectue sa vente  dans sa boutique située au cœur de la gare routière de Sikasso.
Elle envisage réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel de 300 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour augmenter son fonds de commerce, contribuer aux dépenses familiales, rembourser les intérêts du prêt et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en:
Ms. Adiara Berthé, age 54, resides with her husband and their six children in Sanoubougou I, one of the working class districts of the city of Sikasso (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). Having lacked the chance to continue in school due to societal reasons, she got introduced to the dyeing and selling of damask fabrics. This is something she learned from a friend over twenty years ago. After dyeing the damask, she sews a few pieces into men's shirts that she then sells. She is in high demand by her customers (composed essentially of travelers and bus drivers) for the quality of her products.

Concerned with satisfy her growing number of customers better, she decided to join the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso over six years ago. After several solidarity loans (group loans) in a women's association in her area, she is now on her ninth individual loan. All the preceding loans have been correctly repaid. She intends to use this loan to buy ten bolts of white damask, ten boxes of dyes of different colors, ten packets of caustic soda, and a few bolts of Wax pagnes (colorful West Africa cloth). Supplies are gotten in Bamako (capital of Mali), and sales are made in her shop located in the heart of the Sikasso bus station.

With this loan, she envisions realizing a monthly profit of 300,000 francs CFA that will be used essentially to augment her working capital, to help cover family expenses, to pay the loan interest, and to invest the rest her business.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy damask fabric, caustic soda, dyes, etc.

texts.vi: Chị Nguyễn Thị Nga năm nay 52 tuổi, ở Mê Linh - Hà Nội. Chị có hai con đều đã lớn  và đã đi làm. Chị tham gia Quỹ từ năm 2001, hiện nay thu nhập bình quân của gia đình chị là 6.000.000/tháng với nguồn thu chủ yếu từ chăn nuôi bò và lương thợ xây cảu các con. Vòng vốn tới chị mong muốn được vay thêm 10.000.000 để mua thêm bò về nuôi nhằm tạo thêm thu nhập cho gia đình.
texts.en:
Mrs. Nga Thi N. is a 52 years old woman in Me Linh, Hanoi. Both of her two children are construction workers. Mrs. N. joined the TYM fund in 2001 and borrowed money to raise cows. At the moment her family’s income of about 6,000,000 VND per month comes from her business and her children’s salary. She wants to borrow 10,000,000 VND to buy more cows.

Translated from Vietnamese by Duc Tran, Kiva Volunteer

texts.ru: Халимов Абдуманон житель Гиссарского района. Возраст 34 года , женат и имеет троих детей. Имеет пекарню, где выпекает лепешки. Занимается этим видом бизнеса уже 10 лет. Обратился к нам за кредитом . Деньги нужны для закупки муки , которую будет использовать для дела. погасить кредит сможет в течение 12 месяцев.
texts.en:
Abdumanon H. lives in the Gissar region. He is 34 years old, is married and has three children. He has a bakery where he bakes flatbread. Abdumanon has been in this business for 10 years now. He has turned to us for a loan. He needs money to purchase flour, which he will use for his business. He plans to pay back the loan over 12 months.

Translated from Russian by Sabina Holzman, Kiva Volunteer

texts.vi: Chị C. Thị Sự, 55 tuổi, sống cùng chồng và 4 con ở Mê Linh - Hà Nội. Các con của chị đều đã trưởng thành. Chị tham gia Quỹ từ năm 1996 ban đầu chị vay vốn để đầu tư vào chăn nuôi . Sau một thời gian tham gia Quỹ, được vay mức vốn lớn dần anh chị đã quyết định đầu tư vào buôn bán thịt lợn. Hiện tại đây cũng là công việc đem lại nguồn thu chính cho gia đình chị Sự  với thu nhập 5.000.000/tháng. Vòng vốn tới chị mong muốn được vay thêm 10.000.000 để đầu tư thêm vốn cho công việc kinh doanh của gia đình.
texts.en:
Mrs. Su Thi C. is a 55 year old woman. She lives with her husband and 4 children in Me Linh, Hanoi. All of her children are grown-up. In 1996, Mrs. Su joined the TYM fund and borrowed money to invest in livestock. After archiving some successes, the couple decided to switch to selling selling. Now, this business is the main source of the family’s income, about 5,000,000 VND per month. She plans to make the next loan of 10,000,000 VND to expand the business.

Translated from Vietnamese by Duc Tran, Kiva Volunteer

loans.name: Mey's Group

texts.en: A leader S., 38, is a widow mother to one child whom is a student. She owns a general store selling plastic, kid's sweets, cooked ingredients, charcoal, gasoline, noodle ...etc to the whole community since 2000. By the store, she has a lot of customers and she earns a good benefit because she is famous for good service and responsibility. To support her child's education, Seroeun wants to have more income. Seroeun is applying for the loan to build a bigger store and to buy more products for her store. The other group members are: T., 37, who serves rice as the breakfast meal, is taking the loan to invest in her selling. And S., 48, who owns a shop selling groceries, is looking for a loan to buy more products for her shop. They all live in Phnom Penh city, Cambodia. A sister of S. is in picture too.

loans.use: To build a larger store and to buy more products for her store

texts.fr:
Madame  Assitan Traoré  a 45 ans et vit avec ses huit enfants et  son époux dans une famille monogame à Mamassoni, un des  quartiers périphériques de la ville de Sikasso (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
N’ayant pas eu la chance d’aller à l’école pour des raisons sociales, elle s’éssaya à beaucoup d’activités génératrices de revenus. Depuis maintenant  sept  ans elle opta  pour le commerce d’articles divers avec l’achat  vente  de pagnes wax,  d’ustensiles de cuisine (tasse “Super”, tasse nickel, poêles, etc), des jouets d’enfants, des sacs à main pour femmes,  des montres, etc. Elle est beaucoup sollicitée par  sa clientèle (composée essentiellement des femmes) pour la qualité de ses produits. Vu la situation de sa boutique  au bord d’une des artères les plus fréquentées de la ville et d’accès facile,  son activité marche à merveille et la clientèle est très satisfaite.
Dans le souci de mieux satisfaire cette clientèle de plus en plus croissante, elle décida d’intégrer l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso depuis plus de six  ans. Après 6 prêts solidaires (prêt du groupe) dans une association des femmes de son quartier, elle est à son 8ème prêt individuel et tous les prêts précédents ont été correctement remboursés.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                     
Elle compte acheter avec ce prêt 5 pièces de pagnes wax, 3 complets de “Super tasse”, 4 montres, une dizaine de poêle, 5 sacs à main et 10 poupées. Elle s’approvisionne à Dakar (république du Sénégal) et revend dans sa boutique Sikasso.
Elle envisage réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel de 150 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour augmenter son fonds de commerce, contribuer aux dépenses familiales, rembourser les intérêts du prêt et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en:
Ms. Assitan Traoré, age 45, lives with her eight children and husband in a monogamous family in Mamassoni, an outlying district of the city of Sikasso (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). Having lacked the chance to go to school due to societal reasons, she tried many kinds of work to earn an income. Seven years ago, she opted for commerce in various goods, buying and selling Wax pagnes (colorful West Africa cloth), kitchen utensils ("Super" basins, nickel basins, frying pans, etc.) She is in high demand by her customers (composed essentially of women) for the quality of her goods. Given that her shop is located on the roadside of one of the busiest arteries in town, and it has easy access, her business is booming. And her customers are very satisfied.

Wanting to do better in satisfying this ever-growing customer base, she decided to join the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso over six years ago. After six solidarity loans (group loans) in a women's association in her area, she is now on her eighth individual loan. All the preceding loans have been correctly repaid.

She intends to use this loan to buy five bolts of Wax pagnes, three sets of "Super" basins, four wristwatches, a dozen frying pans, five handbags, and ten dolls. The merchandise is gotten in Dakar (Republic of Senegal) and is resold in her shop in Sikasso.

She envisions realizing a monthly profit of 150,000 francs CFA that will be used essentially to augment her working capital, to help cover family expenses, to pay the loan interest, and to invest the rest in her business.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.name: Nilda

texts.en: Nilda L., 35, is a resident of Laredico, Salawagan, Quezon.To complement her husband's income, she engaged in a hog fattening  business and, at the same time, processes native delicacies such as puto (rice cakes), botse (baked goods with coconut filling), siopao and siakoy (sweetened bread formed into a braid). Recently, she received a loan from HSPFI amounting to PHP 15000, which she used to purchase 6 piglets (3 are seen in the picture) to fatten and feed for the animals' daily consumption.  Her long term goal for her business is to improve the cages for long use in the future.

loans.use: To purchase additional piglets and feeds for animals' daily consumption

texts.ru: Файзуллоева Махбуба проживает в районе Гиссар. Возраст 26 лет, замужем и имеет двоих детей. Имеет высшее образование . По специальности экономист. Но по профессии нигде не работала. Уже два года работает в диллерском центре , где продает пластиковые карты и производит денежные переводы. Кроме тогопродает телефоны. Планирует получить кредит для увеличения товарооборота. Погасить кредит сможет в течение 12 месяцев.
texts.en:
Mahbuba F. lives in the Gissar region. She is 26 years old and has two children. She has a college education. For two years now she has been working at a dealer center where she sells plastic cards and makes money transfers. In addition, Mahbuba sells phones. She plans to take out a loan in order to increase her inventory. She can pay back the loan over 12 months.

Translated from Russian by Sabina Holzman, Kiva Volunteer

texts.fr:
O. Houngnidi est née dans le village de Takon,commune de sakété, le 17 mars 1980. Houngnidi vit actuellement dans l'une des localités de son village natif qui est Ahita Boubouta. Houngnidi est mariée et mère de 02 enfants dont 01 seul est scolarisé. Houngnidi est vendeuse des produits finis de noix de palme transformé. N'ayant pas assez d'argent pour s'acheter la matière première-noix de palme- en conséqence, Houngnidi a fait recours à ALIDé.
 
La signification de ALIDé en langue locale du Bénin, le Fon, est « un chemin existe toujours pour les plus pauvres ». Le Bénin est un petit pays de l’Afrique de l’Ouest à coté du Nigeria où le PIB par habitant est à $1,500. ALIDé offre les prêts spéciaux de 0% d’intérêt aux personnes très vulnérables et elle est dans un groupe qui lance bientôt un programme de la micro-assurance santé pour les bénéficiaires de micro crédit.
texts.en:
O. Houngnidi was born in the village of Takon, in the area of sakété, on March 17, 1980. Houngnidi currently lives in one of the areaof the village where she was born, Ahita Boubouta. Houngnidi is married and the mother of 2 children, of whom 1 is in school. Houngnidi is a vendor of finished products of transformed palm nut. Because she does not have sufficient funds to buy the raw materials of palm nut, Houngnidi turned to ALIDé. The meaning of ALIDé in the local language of Benin, the Fon, is « a path always exists for the poorest ». Benin is a small country in West Africa next to Nigeria where the GNP per capita is $1,500. ALIDé offers special 0% loans to very vulnerable people and is part of a group that will soon launch a microinsurance program for the beneficiaries of microcredit.

Translated from French by Isabelle Barres, Kiva Volunteer

loans.name: Amer

texts.en:
Amer is a 22 year old man who lives in Saida, southern Lebanon. Amer has owned a barber shop. He also sells beauty products. Amer requested a loan of 800 US dollars from A. Majmoua in order to purchase merchandise for his salon. This is his second cycle and he has always paid on time. 
His previous loan helped him improve his salon and helped him start selling beauty products. His clients are his friends and neighbors. When Amer first started his business, he had difficulty finding the right place to open the salon. Amer decided on doing his business because he has experience since he learned the business in an academy. In the future, he plans on expanding his business and change his décor.

loans.use: Amer will use the loan to purchase merchandise for his salon.

texts.ru: Даминова Сорохон проживает в городе Турсун-Заде. Возраст 40 лет, замужем и имеет троих детей. Образование среднее. Занимается сельским хозяйством уже 20 лет. Наступил сезон весеннего посева, для которого она решила получить кредит. Погасить кредит сможет в течение 8  месяцев.
texts.en:
Sorohon D. lives in the city of Tursun-zoda. She is 40 years old, married and has three children. She has a secondary education. Sorohon has been involved in agriculture for 20 years. With the coming of the current spring seeding season, she decided to obtain a loan. She will be able to repay this loan within 8 months.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.name: Bakary

texts.fr:
Monsieur  Bakary Berthé  a 47 ans, polygame et père de huit  enfants (4 garçons et 4 filles). Il vit avec ses deux femmes et ses enfants à Hamdallaye, un des quartiers populaires de la ville de Sikasso (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
 N’ayant pas eu la chance d’aller à l’école, il s’est vite initié aux activités de commercialisation des engrais, pesticides et insecticides. Avec une expérience  de plus de 20 ans dans ce domaine, il jouit d’une forte réputation et reçoit beaucoup de commandes.
Dans ses recherches de ressources  financières complémentaires afin d’étoffer son fonds de commerce, il  décide de collaborer avec Soro Yiriwaso. Il est à son premier prêt individuel  qu’il compte utiliser pour acheter, 4 sacs d’urées, 4 sacs de complexe coton et 4 sacs de complexe maïs.
Il s’approvisionne auprès de la  représentation de TOGUNA (une usine de fabrique d’engrais) à Sikasso et effectue sa vente dans son magasin au nouveau marché du quartier  Médine  de Sikasso   au comptant et à crédit à une clientèle composée majoritairement  d’agriculteurs.
Avec ce prêt, il envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 60 000 FCFA. Avec ces bénéfices réalisés, il compte résoudre l’essentielle de ses dépenses, celles de sa famille, rembourser les intérêts du prêt et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en:
Mr. Bakary Berthé, age 47, is polygamous and the father of 8 children (4 boys and 4 girls). He lives with his two wives and his children in Hamdallaye, a working-class neighborhood in the city of Sikasso (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). Never having had the chance to attend school, he learned early on the business of selling fertilizers, pesticides, and insecticides. With 20 years of experience in this field, he enjoys a strong reputation and gets many orders. Looking for complementary financial resources in order to bolster his working capital, he decided to join Kiva's partner Soro Yiriwaso. He's seeking his first individual loan, which he intends to use to buy the following fertilizers : 4 sacks of urea, 4 sacks of "cotton complex" and 4 sacks of "corn complex". He gets his supplies from TOGUNA (a fertilizer factory) in Sikasso and sells his products in his shop at the new market of the Médine quarter in Sikasso. He sells for cash or on credit, to a clientele comprising mostly farmers. With this loan, he foresees turning a monthly profit of XOF 60'000 (ca US$ 125), which he plans to to use to provide for his family expenses, to repay the loan, and to invest in his business.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy and resell 12 sacks of fertilizers

texts.ru: Насриддинов Тохирджон житель Гиссарского района. Возраст 29 лет, женат и имеет троих детей. Образование среднее. Работает на стройке . Кроме того занимается земледелием , на что  и запрашивает кредит. Имеет участок земли , который засеивает картофелем и другими овощами. Получаемую продукцию продает и получает за это доход. Планирует использовать кредит для покупки семян и удобрений. Погасить кредит сможет в течение 8 месяцев.
texts.en:
Tohirjon N. lives in the Gissar district. He is 29 years, married and has three children. He has a secondary education and works in construction. Besides this work, he is involved in agriculture, for which he is requesting a loan. Tohirjon owns a plot of land where he plants potatoes and other vegetables. He picks and sells the vegetables for profit. Tohirjon plans to use this loan to purchase seeds and fertilizer. He will be able to repay the loan within 8 months.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

texts.fr:
Originaire de Takon, commune de sakété, D. Ouinsi est née le 24 Avril 1978 à Ahita Boubouta dans l'un des villages de Takon. Ouinsi est mariée et mère de 02 enfants dont un seul est scolarisé. Oiunsi est une transformatrice de noix de palme dont elle commercialise le produit fini, huile rouge. Pour renforcer son activité génératrice de revenu et constitué son propre capital ce qui lui permettra d'être indépendante financièrement, Ouinsi exprime un besoin de prêt.
 
La signification de ALIDé en langue locale du Bénin, le Fon, est « un chemin existe toujours pour les plus pauvres ». Le Bénin est un petit pays de l’Afrique de l’Ouest à coté du Nigeria où le PIB par habitant est à $1,500. ALIDé offre les prêts spéciaux de 0% d’intérêt aux personnes très vulnérables et elle est dans un groupe qui lance bientôt un programme de la micro-assurance santé pour les bénéficiaires de micro crédit.
texts.en:
Originally from Takon, area of sakété, D. Ouinsi was born on April 24, 1978 in Ahita Boubouta in one of the villages of Takon. Ouinsi is married and the mother of 2 children, of whom only 1 is in school. Oiunsi transforms palm nuts, of which she sells the finished products, red oil. To strengthen her revenue generating activity and build her own capital that will enable her to be financially independent, Ouinsi expresses the need for a loan. The meaning of ALIDé in the local language of Benin, the Fon, is « a path always exists for the poorest ». Benin is a small country in West Africa next to Nigeria where the GNP per capita is $1,500. ALIDé offers special 0% loans to very vulnerable people and is part of a group that will soon launch a microinsurance program for the beneficiaries of microcredit.

Translated from French by Isabelle Barres, Kiva Volunteer

loans.name: Djita

texts.fr:
Madame Djita Sidibé a 28 ans, mariée et mère d’une fille de 6 ans. Elle réside avec sa fille  et son époux dans la grande famille élargie  à Bougoula-Ville, un quartier du centre ville de Sikasso ( troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Enseignante de formation, elle mène une activité de fabrication de jus de fruits, de la glace, du yaourt et de boisson non alcoolisée il y a environ trois  ans. Elle jouit d’une grande réputation dans ce secteur.
Dans le souci de mieux satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, elle a décidé d’intégrer l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso depuis plus de six  ans. Après 6 prêts solidaires (prêt du groupe) dans une association des femmes de son quartier (Association Teriya de Hamdallaye), elle est à son premier prêt individuel  et  tous les prêts précédents ont été correctement remboursés.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          
Elle compte acheter avec ce prêt un réfrigérateur supplémentaire et quelques matières premières telles que le sucre, le lait, boissons, etc.
 Elle s’approvisionne à Sikasso et effectue ses ventes   à l’école à une clientèle composée d’élèves, de collègues de l’école et aussi des voisins.
Elle envisage réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel de 150 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour augmenter son fonds de commerce, contribuer aux dépenses familiales et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en:
Ms. Djita Sidibé, age 28, is married and the mother of a 6-year-old girl. She resides with her daughter in Bougoula-Ville, a district in downtown Sikasso (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). A teacher by training, she has been working for about three years making fruit juices, ice, yoghurt, and soft drinks. She enjoys a great reputation in this field of business.

Concerned with doing better in satisfying her burgeoning customer base, she decided to join the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso over six years ago. After six solidarity loans (group loans) in a women’s association in her area (Association Teriya de Hamdallaye), she is now on her first individual loan. All the preceding loans have been correctly repaid.

She intends to use this loan to buy an extra refrigerator and a few essential goods, such as sugar, milk, beverages, etc. Supplies are gotten in Sikasso, and sales are made at the school, to customers composed of middle-school students there and also neighbors.

With this loan, she envisions realizing a monthly profit of 150,000 francs CFA that will be used essentially to augment her working capital, to help cover family expenses, and to invest the rest in her business.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy a refrigerator and ingredients for juices and yoghurt

texts.en:
Linda A. is 30 years old and is married. Her husband is a peasant. They have 3 children who go to school. Linda is currently in the business of selling charcoal. She is requesting a loan to expand her business. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a shop.

BRAC, an international development organization, started operations in Southern Sudan in 2007. BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs (Non Goverment Organizations) as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In Sudan the microfinance program, which is targeted to returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

texts.vi:
Chị Miên 27 tuổi đang sống cùng chồng  và hai con tại huyện Hưng Nguyên tỉnh Nghệ An . Chị  tham gia Quỹ tình thương từ năm 2006. Hiện tại hai vợ chồng chị đang là chủ cửa hàng chuyên kinh doanh bia hơi. Bên cạnh chăn nuôi, đây cũng là một trongn hững công việc đem alị cho gia đình  chị nguồn thu nhập ổn định 3.000.000đ/ tháng
Vòng vốn tới chị Miên mong muốn được vay 15.000.000đ để đầu tư cho công việc kinh doanh của gia đình.
texts.en:
Mrs M., 27 years old, is currently living with her husband and two children at Hung Nguyen district, Nghe An province. She has been a member of TYM Fund (Kiva Partner in Vietnam) since 2006. Currently her husband and she are the owners of a beer store. Besides raising cattle, the beer store is also a stable source of income to their family, which is about 3,000,000 VND per month. This time Mrs. M. would like to borrow 15,000,000 VND to invest in their business.

Translated from Vietnamese by Phuong Nguyen, Kiva Volunteer

loans.name: Rin's Group

texts.en: This group of borrowers consists of three members. Its leader, S., 55, is a mother of three children: all of them are students. She is married to Dy, 44, who is a motor taxi driver. S. has been selling Khmer noodles since 1990 to the whole commune. She is famous for making tasty food and she is a responsible neighbor. She earns a good income for her family. She has a big piece of land behind her house that she could possibly use to start another business for her family's income. Therefore, S. decided to take a loan to buy piglets for the family to raise. The other group members are: S., 37, who sells a kind of junk food (fried banana) and is taking a loan to pay for the electric service into her home; and T., 54, who works as security for a private company, wants a loan to buy a fan and home accessories for the family.

loans.use: To buy piglets for the family to raise

texts.ru: Мирзоева Саъбатгуль проживает в районе Абдурахмони Джоми. Возраст 50 лет, замужем и имеет шестерых детей. Занимается животноводством уже 12 лет. Этот бизнес является единственным источником дохода ее семьи. Поэтому она решил развивать бизнес и увеличить поголовье скота.В данный момент она планирует получить кредит для того, чтобы купит пару голов бычков, которых она сможет реализовать после откормки. Погасить кредит сможет в течение 8 месяцев.
texts.en:
Sabatgul M. lives in the Abdurahmon Jomi district. She is 50 years old, married and has six children. She has been involved in animal husbandry for 12 years. This business solely supports her family. This is why Sabatgul decided to develop her business and increase the livestock headcount. Currently, she plans to obtain a loan in order to purchase a couple of bulls to raise and sell. She will be able to repay this loan within 8 months.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.name: Issa

texts.fr:
Monsieur  Issa Diamoutènè  a 38 ans, polygame et père de six  enfants, il réside avec ses quatre  femmes et leurs enfants  à Médine, un des quartiers populaires de la ville de Sikasso (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Après avoir mené plusieurs activités sans succès notamment l’agriculture et autres, il s’est vite initié aux activités de stockage et de  commercialisation de Pois Sucré et noix de karité il y a environ 10 ans. Avec une telle expérience dans ce domaine, il jouit d’une forte réputation et reçoit beaucoup de commandes de l’extérieur.
Les ressources financières lui faisant défaut, il sollicite la collaboration de Soro Yiriwaso avec qui il est à  son premier prêt individuel qu’il utilisera pour acheter, 20 sacs de pois sucré et 10 sacs de noix de karité. 
ll s’approvisionne dans les localités environnantes de Sikasso,  pour venir les stocker dans son magasin situé au nouveau de Médine Sikasso, ensuite il les achemine sur Abidjan et à Bobo Dioulasso (respectivement en république de la Côte d’Ivoire et au Burkina Faso) sur commande des usines de fabrique de jus de pois sucré et de beurre de karité.  
Avec ce prêt, il envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 250 000 FCFA. Avec ces bénéfices réalisés, il compte résoudre l’essentielle de ses dépenses, celles de sa famille et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en:
Mr. Issa Diamoutènè, age 38, is polygamous and the father of six children. He resides with his four wives and their children in Médine, a working-class district of the city of Sikasso (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). After having done several kinds of work unsuccessfully, notably agriculture, he got introduced about ten years ago to the business of storing and marketing sugar peas and shea nuts. With such experience in this domain, he enjoys a fine reputation and receives many orders from abroad.

With financial resources lacking, he’s applying to collaborate with Soro Yiriwaso, with which he is on his first individual loan. This loan will be used to buy 20 sacks of sugar peas and 10 sacks of shea nuts. Supplies are gotten in towns surrounding Sikasso in order to stock them in his store located in Médine Sikasso. Next he takes them to Abidjan and to Bobo Dioulasso (respectively in the Republic of Cote d’Ivoire and in Burkina Faso) by special order from factories making sweet pea juice and shea butter.

With this loan, he envisions realizing a monthly profit of 250,000 francs CFA. With these profits in hand, he intends to cover most of the expenses for him and his family and to invest the rest in his business.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy sugar peas and shea nuts

loans.name: Jackline

texts.en:
Jackline I. is currently in the business of selling onions and cooking oil. She is requesting a loan to expand her business. Jackline is 25 years old and is married to a man who is a driver. She has one child who does not go to school. With the extra profit from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a hotel.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Expand her business and open a hotel

texts.ru: Каримова Зуфнун проживает  в районе Абдурахмони Джоми. Возраст 42 года , замужем и имеет шестерых детей. Домохозяйка , но занимается животноводством. Планирует получить кредит для того, чтобы купить дойную корову. Получаемое молоко , она сможет продавать и получать прибыль , с которой она сможет расплатиться за кредит.Таким образом корова , купленная на кредит останеться ей . Погасить кредит она сможет в течение 8 месяцев.
texts.en:
Zufnun K. lives in the Abdurahmon Jomi district. She is 42 years old, married and has six children. She is a homemaker, but is also involved in animal husbandry. She plans to obtain this loan in order to buy a dairy cow. Zufnun would sell the milk and receive a profit, which she would be able to use to repay the loan. This will also allow her to keep the dairy cow. She can repay the loan within 8 months.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

texts.fr:
AHISSOU Ahinadjè est née à Porto Novo, capitale administrative et politique du Bénin. Ahinadjè est mariée et mère de 02 enfants tous scolarisés. Ahinadjè vit actuellement à Takon dans commune de Sakété, département de Plateau. Ahinadjè est vendeuse d'huile rouge qu'elle obtient après transformation de noix de palme. Ahinadjè a besoin de se constituer un fonds de roulement conséquent afin d'avoir plus de revenu dans cette activité de transformation de noix de palme. C'est pourquoi Ahinadjè s'est adressée à ALIDé pour avoir un crédit. 

 
La signification de ALIDé en langue locale du Bénin, le Fon, est « un chemin existe toujours pour les plus pauvres ». Le Bénin est un petit pays de l’Afrique de l’Ouest à coté du Nigeria où le PIB par habitant est à $1,500. ALIDé offre les prêts spéciaux de 0% d’intérêt aux personnes très vulnérables et elle est dans un groupe qui lance bientôt un programme de la micro-assurance santé pour les bénéficiaires de micro crédit.
texts.en:
AHISSOU Ahinadjè was born in Porto Novo, administrative and political capital of Benin. Ahinadjè is married and the mother of 2 children, all in school. Ahinadjè currently lives in Takon in the area of Sakété, department of the Plains. Ahinadjè sells red oil that she obtains after transforming palm nut. Ahinadjè needs to build meaningful capital in order to generate more revenue from this activity of palm nut transformation. This is why Ahinadjè came to ALIDé to get a loan. The meaning of ALIDé in the local language of Benin, the Fon, is « a path always exists for the poorest ». Benin is a small country in West Africa next to Nigeria where the GNP per capita is $1,500. ALIDé offers special 0% loans to very vulnerable people and is part of a group that will soon launch a microinsurance program for the beneficiaries of microcredit.

Translated from French by Isabelle Barres, Kiva Volunteer

loans.name: Salif

texts.fr:
Monsieur  Salif Y.  a 50 ans, polygame et père de sept  enfants, il réside avec ses deux femmes et ses enfants à Sanoubougou I, un des quartiers populaires de la ville de Sikasso (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
N’ayant pas eu la chance d’aller à l’école et après avoir mené plusieurs activités sans succès, il s’est vite initié aux activités commerciales notamment l’achat-vente des appareils électroniques (radios, cassette, panneaux Satellitaires, Antennes Paraboliques, Batteries et divers) il y a maintenant plus de 25 ans. Il rejouit d’une forte réputation dans ce secteur et reçoit beaucoup de commandes.
Dans ses recherches de ressources financières complémentaires, il sollicite la collaboration de l’institution avec qui  il est à son  2ème prêt individuel  qui lui permettra d’acheter 15 radios de marques différentes, 2 panneaux satellitaires, 5 batteries blindées, 5 antennes paraboliques et 200 cassettes. 
Il  s’approvisionne à Bamako pour venir  revendre à Sikasso dans sa boutique sise à la gare routière à côté de la compagnie Kènèdougou Voyage. Parallèlement à sa boutique, il vend aussi des téléphones portables par commande. Il a comme clients les voyageurs, les routiers etc. Certains de ses clients payent au comptant et d’autres à crédit. 
Avec ce prêt, il envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 400 000 FCFA. Avec ces bénéfices réalisés, il compte résoudre l’essentielle de ses dépenses, celles de sa famille, rembourser les intérêts du prêt et investir le reste dans son activité principale.
texts.en:
Mr. Salif Y., age 50, is polygamous and the father of seven children. He resides with his two wives and his children in Sanoubougou I, a working-class district of the city of Sikasso (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). Having lacked the chance to go to school, and after having done several kinds of work unsuccessfully, he got introduced over 25 years ago to commercial business, notably buying and selling electronic equipment (radios, cassettes, solar panels, satellite dishes, batteries, etc.) He enjoys a fine reputation in this domain and receives many orders.

In his search for added financial resources, he applied to collaborate with the institution (Soro Yiriwaso micro-financing) and is now on his second individual loan, which will enable him to buy 15 radios of various brands, 2 solar panels, 5 shielded batteries, 5 satellite dishes, and 200 cassettes. Supplies are gotten in Bamako to be sold in Sikasso in his shop located at the bus station next to the Kènèdougou Voyage company. Along with his shop, he also sells mobile phones by special order. For customers, he has travelers, bus drivers, etc. Certain customers pay cash and others, on credit.

With this loan, he envisions realizing a monthly profit of 400,000 francs CFA. With these profits in hand, he intends to cover most of his expenses and those of his family, to make the interest payments, and to invest the rest in his main business.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy radios, solar panels, satellite dishes, batteries, and K7 cassettes

texts.ru: Холова Дилафруз проживает  в районе Абдурахмони Джоми. Возраст 25 лет, замужем и имеет одного ребенка.Уже четыре года занимается животноводством. Планирует получиь кредит для того, чтобы купить дойную корову. Молоко будет использовать для своей семьи , а лишнее будет продавать соседям .
